name: Der Präsident. –
text: In agreement with the political groups, I have convened this extraordinary part-session in accordance with the second subparagraph of Rule 146(4) of the Rules of Procedure, so that Parliament can debate the outcome of the referendum in the United Kingdom. It is the first time that a plenary session in this form has been convened so quickly. This exceptional measure is, of course, also a response to an exceptional precedent, namely that a Member State has decided to withdraw from the Community. I therefore very much welcome the fact that the entire College of Commissioners, including Lord Hill, is here today and I warmly welcome you, Mr President of the Commission, to the Members of the Commission! (Applause) It is important that we have a debate today in Parliament, in the place of European democracy, on the subject that deeply affects us all. Because, ladies and gentlemen, contrary to popular commentary in some institutions, the decision taken in the United Kingdom is a decision of the British people, but one that affects all the citizens of the European Union. That is why it makes sense for the Members of the peoples of Europe to discuss this case here in this House today. However, let me say one thing at the beginning of our debate: over four decades, many politicians and, in particular, a great many UK civil servants have worked in the EU institutions. Personally, like many of you, I have worked together with colleagues from the United Kingdom for decades to build our House of Europe. That is why It is a great need for me – and I think I am speaking on your behalf – that we say to all those Members from the United Kingdom here in this House and, above all, to the hundreds of men and women in the political groups and in the committees, in the administration of this House, who have worked with us on the European project, on this day. : We deeply regret the decision that Britain wants to leave us. But to you – colleagues who have worked with us over the years – we are deeply attached to you politically and humanly! (Applause) It is clear to all of us, ladies and gentlemen, that the value of the United Kingdom, especially in Europe's foreign policy, but also in the defence of its freedoms, is of the utmost importance. However, the will of the majority of UK citizens must also be activated and respected. That is why we will certainly discuss the issue of Article 50 and its activation in depth today. Ladies and gentlemen! Let me thank someone who is in the room who, in a very difficult situation, I think has done a great job and taken a great human step. Lord Hill has made his position as Commissioner of the United Kingdom available as a consequence of his own position. That is why he is certainly with us today for the last time. I would like to tell you, Lord Hill, that you campaigned for the Uk to remain. I would like to thank you, on behalf of Parliament, for your commitment, but also for your work in the Commission. (Members of Parliament rose and applauded Lord Hill) I thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for this signal, which also shows which side the overwhelming majority of the Members of the European peoples stand on: on the side of those who wanted to keep Britain in the European Union. Thank you for this strong signal! At the same time, however, the resignation of Lord Hill is certainly already a signal that the de facto exit procedure has already begun.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission statements on the outcome of the referendum in the United Kingdom (2016/2800(RSP)). First of all, Mrs Hennis-Plasschaert has the floor for the European Council. I had invited Mr Tusk to our meeting today, as did Prime Minister Rutte. However, this does not alter our respect for you, Mrs Hennis-Plasschaert, who is representing the Council here today. You have the floor!

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Honourable Members, Members of the College of Commissioners, 23 June 2016 will go down in history as a day that shook the United Kingdom and the European Union. A majority of British voters have expressed their wish to leave the EU. Following this result, which we respect, there is deep, deep regret but there is also a strong resolve to show unity in our response. However, let me underscore the fact that today I represent the full Council, all 28 members of it. Until a UK exit is finalised, the UK will be a member of the Council with all the rights and obligations that derive from this.  The United Kingdom has been a respected member of the European Union since 1973, working with Member States and institutions to build and strengthen a secure and prosperous Europe. The outcome of the referendum therefore marks a watershed moment in Europe’s history. But history and geography cannot be changed. The UK is, and will always be, a European nation. We share the same values, we harbour the same hopes and we will continue to work together as partners and allies. In other words, it will be in the interest of us all to ensure that a future relationship will be constructive and mutually beneficial.  Let me absolutely clear. No one will benefit from a prolonged period of political limbo. The ball is in the British court and we look forward to hearing from London soon. At the same time, let us also allow the UK the time it needs to recuperate and to take the necessary decisions so we can indeed move forward. In other words, cool heads must now prevail.  Since its creation in 1957, the EU has gone a long and successful way. It has reunited Eastern and Western Europe and it has brought about the longest period of peace on our continent in modern times. It has been a driving force to bring and keep the people of Europe together in all its diversity and strength. Never in modern history have we enjoyed so much freedom, so much wealth and so much stability in Europe. Why did people give their lives in Ukraine, carrying a blue banner with golden stars? Why do people from Africa and Asia leave their families to reach our shores in rickety boats? It is because of the fundamental values that bind us, the fundamental freedoms that inspire us, and the promise that, if you do your best, you can really get ahead and, if you cannot, you will not be cast away. These achievements stand and we can be proud to have contributed to them. However, nothing is irreversible, nothing inevitable. The shock of the referendum should be a wake—up call to us all. Whether we like it or not, the sentiments of a large part of the British voters are shared in many other EU Member States. So we will have to do better. We must intensify our efforts. We need a more efficient, more effective and, most of all, a more convincing European Union.  Clearly, in this globalised world, Europe is facing huge challenges. So yes, we do need an EU that is protecting its borders and controlling migration, an EU that is providing economic opportunities for all citizens, and an EU that is keeping threats at bay. We need an EU that is not seen as a threat to national identity but as an extension of our identities, an EU that is not seen as a bureaucratic meddler, but as a facilitator.  The inconvenient truth is that neither Europe as a whole, nor any single nation, can isolate itself from a world in turmoil. We must cope with this turmoil together, as best we can, or else the zone of peace and stability that we have built up over decades might disintegrate, and we would have no one to blame but ourselves.  We need unity because geopolitical tension and the conflicts surrounding Europe will continue and possibly even multiply. We need unity because terrorists will not hesitate to strike at us again. We need unity to control the huge flows of migrants that will continue to move towards this continent.  Let me be clear once more. No country on the face of the earth can meet these challenges alone. These challenges are simply too complex. They also tend to ignore borders. It is true that part of the challenge lies in the domestic realm, convincing European citizens that unity remains the best choice. But fancy words, conclusions and declarations will not be enough. We have to act. The fact that fragmentation is no longer considered unthinkable should gravely concern us all and propel us into action. There is no reason to be fatalistic, for together we are still strong. Together, we are the world’s strongest advocates for the values we cherish: the rule of law, freedom, democracy, a market-based economy. But it would be foolish to underestimate the challenge at hand.  The outcome of the referendum has left us with an unprecedented situation. Many within the UK and other Member States feel uncertain about the consequences. It is in the interest of all to have clarity about the way ahead soon. At the same time, it is important to recall that we have the rules to deal with this situation in an orderly way. As we all know, Article 50 of the Treaty sets out the procedure to be followed if a Member State decides to leave the European Union. The EU stands ready to launch negotiations swiftly, but it is up to the UK Government, and no one else, to trigger Article 50. Negotiations can only start after such a notification has taken place.  Meanwhile, we have some work to do. Clearly, the outcome of the UK referendum does not mean that the threats and challenges we commonly face have suddenly disappeared. Neither does it mean that each nation will be better off acting on its own, rather than as part of a collective. On the contrary, I would say.  If the UK indeed decides to leave, the Union of 27 Member States will continue. Together we can – and will – address our common challenge to generate growth, to increase prosperity, and to ensure a safe and secure environment for our citizens. This is what European citizens expect from us, and rightly so. While institutional debates on treaty changes and conventions are a paradise for lawyers and diplomats, they are a hell for citizens. So we simply need to grit our teeth, roll up our sleeves and use all the tools and means we have. True, it will not always be easy to agree on what we should do. It is no doubt challenging to make cooperation work, but we have to forge ahead, for the failure to do so is equal to jeopardising prosperity and well-being, and that would be reckless.  In closing, the European Council will meet in a few hours. You will understand that I cannot prejudge the discussions in the Council, in other words, I cannot go into greater detail on the next steps. However, I will listen carefully to your debate. You yourself, President Schulz, will be able to address the members of the Council this afternoon when you meet them, and to convey the substance of the debate and of the resolutions you will adopt later this morning.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. Mr President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, your Parliament is about to discuss the future of Europe and the uk's place in Europe or near the European Union.  I had a lot of meetings this morning, but I decided to come to the European Parliament. I believe that my place, now and now, is here, in European democracy. (Great applause)  Our British friends expressed themselves by means of universal suffrage. It is obvious that the expression of the majority will of the British calls for respect for everyone. Democracy is democracy, and we must respect British democracy and the expression it has chosen to give itself. (addressing UKIP Members) That is the last time you will be applauding here. (Laughter from Mr Farage and loud applause from the House)  And to some extent I am really surprised that you are here. You were fighting for the exit. The British people voted in favour of the exit. Why are you here? (Loud applause) So the expression of British universal suffrage calls for respect. I do not dare to say that I am a friend of democracy, because I must not prove that I am, but I must respect the choice of british citizens.  Expression there was, consequence there must be. I therefore ask for clarification, not immediate, because the British system is more complicated than we thought. There was a vote, there is hesitation. Lord Hill, my friend and colleague has drawn the consequences, he is a true Democrat. (Applause) I would like others to draw the consequences of the expression of British universal suffrage. I have read, I have heard that the President of Parliament, that the Chairs of the parliamentary groups, all but a few, would have reacted in a sentimental way to the results of the British vote. Europe is not just a matter of cerebrality. Yes, you have to keep it right, but you also have to be allowed to say that you are sad when you are sad. I am sad after this British vote, and I am not hiding it. (Applause) It is not , how to say - sentimentalism, it is my deep conviction. I wish the United Kingdom would always be with us and with us. He has decided otherwise, and the consequences must be drawn. I ask the British government to clarify things. I will see the Prime Minister later in the morning — he remains a friend, because the British remain our friends despite their vote — and I will ask him to clarify the situation as soon as possible. We cannot settle in prolonged uncertainty. (Applause) If I say I'm sad, even if, apparently, feelings no longer prevail in political life, it's because I'm not a robot. I'm not the bureaucrat, the technocrat that ...  (Protests) You are "office-exit"; I'm not a bureaucrat, I'm not a technocrat. The Commission was elected by this house, we had a democratic process with the lead candidates, which led to the result that you do not like, but we are here as human beings. I am not a robot, I am not a machine, I am a human being, I am a European, and therefore I have the right to say that I regret the British vote. (Applause) I would like the United Kingdom to clarify its position. Not today, not tomorrow morning at 9:00, but fast. We cannot move into a period of prolonged uncertainty. Unlike others, I am not a slave to financial markets, but I watch them.  You are. I am not. But it reflects a general and global feeling. I would like the United Kingdom, as I have just said, to clarify its position. I would not want the idea to take hold that there could be secret negotiations in the darkened chamber, with curtains drawn, between representations of the United Kingdom, national governments, commissioners and directors-general. I have forbidden - by presidential order, which is not my type - to the commissioners to discuss with the representatives of the British government in or out, leave or remain. I have told all the Directors General that there can be no prior discussion with the British representatives. No notification, no negotiation. (Loud applause) By the expression of British universal suffrage, we have lost one of our many wings. There are the wings of the founding Member States, which have no more rights than the others. Even though they started the project, they are not the only ones carrying out the project. The others, the so-called new Member States, are full Member States, and I welcome once again the unification, reconciliation between the geography and European history. Welcome to the new Member States. The British vote has cut off some of our many wings, but we continue to fly. We are not going to stop our flight to the future. The horizons await us, and we fly to the horizons that are those of Europe and the whole planet.  You should know that those who are watching us from afar are worried. I have seen, heard and listened to many of the leaders of other countries. They are very concerned because they are wondering about the path that the European Union will now follow. We must therefore reassure the Europeans and those who are watching us from further afield.  The flight continues. This is not a flight to full adventure, it is a flight to a goal determined by the treaties and by the will of many Europeans. The flight continues and, although our pace is somewhat held back by the British vote, we must make progress towards the goals that we share with renewed ambition.  Imagine that the Commission did not present to Parliament the ten priorities that Parliament approved by a majority. What would be the answer to our British friends? Of course, that would be the Commission's programme. Will we, following the British vote, end our generally accepted, not always appreciated, effort to end an overflowing bureaucracy in Europe? No! We will continue to fight against what the British and others call red tape. We need less bureaucracy in Europe. We are working on it and we will continue to do so. As a Commission, we have said that social Europe will regain its rightful place in Europe. We have launched a broad consultation on the social rights pillar. Do you really want us to stop this exercise after the British vote? No! Europe must become more social and it will become more social. As a college, we have put an end to blind unilateralism, which wanted austerity alone to be the answer to the economic, financial and social crisis. I dare not say it any more, we have flexibilized, in the noble sense of the word, the interpretation of the Stability Pact. Do you really want us, following the British vote, to return to the world as it was before this Commission took office? No! The Stability Pact must be applied wisely and with heart. We'll do it.  We have launched a project on the energy union. Do you really want - because everyone says we have to change everything without ever saying what needs to change - that we put an end to this continental effort to cut ourselves off from dependence on Russia and secure europe's energy supply? No! We will continue on this path.  We wanted to modernise Europe, as we have said many times, which is why we have launched an ambitious project on the digital future of the European Union. Everything needs to be changed, but do we need to change that? No! The Commission, I say to you, will continue on the path we took with Parliament's agreement at the beginning of its mandate. While everyone says that everything must be changed, without saying what needs to change, the Commission feels comforted, in particular, in support of this Parliament in continuing on the road, on the avenue, which we took in November 2014. We have to change everything, yes, but we must not change the essentials. The main thing is that Europe remains a project of peace and a project for the future. That is what I am committing to in this House. I am neither tired nor sick as the German newspapers write - would doctors be journalists? –; I remain what I am, and I go to my last breath to fight for a united Europe. (Great applause) Sehr verehrter Herr President, meine Damen und Herren! Die Stunde ist ernst. Ich here gerne denen zu, die sagen, man solle jetzt besonnen reagieren, abwartend. Ich bin - das wird einige 'berraschen' ein sehr besonnener Mensch, aber ich mag Unsicherheit nicht. Ich hette gerne, dass unsere britischen Freunde jetzt sagen, was Sache ist, und dass sie das so schnell wie m-glich sagen werden. Ich habe mich am Freitagmorgen mit President Schulz, President Tusk und President Rutte getroffen. Wir haben uns darauf verst-ndigt, unsere britischen Freunde zu bitten, so schnell wie meglich Klarheit zu schaffen. Ich bin einigermaen overrascht. Ich, der ich in Groebritannien regelm-ig als Nicht-Demokrat beschrieben werde, als Berokrat, als Technokrat, als handelnde Maschine, als Roboter - dass ich bereit bin, das Votum der Briten zur Kenntnis zu nehmen, aber dass man sich in Groebritannien schwer damit tut, dieses Votum zur Kenntnis zu nehmen, das ist doch eine Ich respektiere das, was die Briten zum Ausdruck gebracht haben. Ich hette auch gerne, dass man in Groebritannien respektiert, was das britische Volk zum Ausdruck gebracht hat, und dass man entsprechend konsequent reagiert anstatt sich jetzt in Schattenspiele, in Katz- und Mausspiele zu flàchten. Dies ist nicht die Interpretation of the Whlerwillens. Die Interpretation of the Wàhlerwillens ist klar und deutlich: Die Briten mechten raus aus der European Union - dementsprechend sollte man handeln.  (Beifall) Ich bin sehr dagegen - ich sage dies ganz deutlich: Es kann nicht sein, dass die jetzige oder die zuk-nftige britische Regierung jetzt klammheimlich versucht, in abgedunkelten Ràumen so informal Geheimverhandlungen zu beginnen. Das wird nicht passieren. Ich habe, was ich selten mache, einen Mufti-Befehl an alle Kommissare und alle Generaldirektoren ausgesandt, dass jetzt keine geheimen Verhandlungen stattfinden. Das kann nicht sein! (Beifall) Aber wir messen nat-rlich wissen - das sagt uns der gesunde Menschenverstand - dass wir mit Groebritannien eine neue Beziehung herbeif-hren messen. Aber wie diese neue Beziehung aussieht, h-ngt nicht nur von dem geheimen Verhandlungswillen der britischen Unterh-ndler ab, sondern auch von uns: Wir bestimmen die Tagesordnung und nicht diejenigen, die die Europ-ische Union verlassen mechten. (Beifall) Der European Traum geht weiter. Wir werden daran arbeiten messen: beharrlich, konsequent, mit erneuerter Energie und mit einer Wiederbelebung der kontinentalen Ambitionen. Jetzt ist nicht die Stunde der Nabelschau - weder fer uns, noch fer Groebritannien. Was wir brauchen, ist ein Blick auf den gesamten kontinentalen Kurper; den hat die Kommission im Auge. Wir sollten daran denken, obwohl dies altmodisch klingt - ich werde ja regelm-ig als altmodischer Veteran beschrieben - was eigentlich die Geburtsstunde dieses europeischen Traums war. Das ist nicht gegessen und nicht vergessen.  Europa bleibt ein Friedensprojekt. Den jungen Menschen - auch in Groebritannien, die sich ja mehrheitlich fer einen Verbleib Groebritanniens in der Europ-ischen Union ausgesprochen haben - mechte ich sagen: Jetzt ist nicht die Stunde der Wiederzerst-ckelung des Kontinentes gekommen.  Am Anfang of 20. Jahrhunderts gab es 20% European auf dem Globus. Am Ende dieses Jahrhunderts wird es von 10 Milliarden Menschen noch 4% European geben. Wir sind nicht die dominierende global Macht. Der Anteil Europas an der globalen Wertsch-pfung wird dramatisch abnehmen, und wir sind der kleinste Kontinent. Die drei Dinge sollten wir im Auge behalten.  Man kann Europa nicht nur retrospektiv erklunren; das galt fer die Generation meines Vaters. Das gilt nicht mehr fer die jungen Menschen, die dabei sind, erwachsen zu werden, und die morgen unsere Gesellschaften animieren und unsere Londer regieren werden. Die Zukunft geh-rt der Jugend Europas. (Lebhafter Beifall)

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, please let me start with the words of a young man from Britain who said: 'We will never know exactly what extent we will miss opportunities, friendships, weddings and experiences. A whole young generation is in shock. More than 73% of young British wanted to stay European. Their hopes have been destroyed. (Sustained applause) The politicians who fought for Brexit had the privilege to live in a Europe without walls, without nationalism. They are now erecting new walls. We say our message today is: 'The young generation of the United Kingdom can continue to trust in their friends in Europe. We don't leave you on your own'. (Applause) Yes, it is a victory for the populists. The jubilation of the nationalists on both sides of the Channel shows us: Europe's future is now at a crossroads. The demagogues, from the left and from the right, want to destroy Europe, and since Thursday everybody in Europe must know what is at stake: division or cooperation, walls or bridges, nationalism or Europe. And on one thing we must be clear: today there is no EPP, no Liberals, no Socialists, no Greens. Today only one thing counts: we, the vast majority of this House, stood for the idea of a united, peaceful and tolerant Europe, and the populists should know this. We stood by this Europe today more than ever before. (Applause) And someone else has won too. Those who spread hate and who use any tool they can find, even read. The worst liars can be found among UKIP. (Applause mixed with catcalls from UKIP) On Friday Nigel Farage said publicly that the promised GBP 350 million per week would finally not go to the National Health Service. It had all been a lie. I ask Mr Farage: if you had an ounce of decency in you would apologise today to the British. Shame on you. (Sustained applause) And I admit I have also made a mistake. I have kept silent. I haven't voiced my opinion, and for the future it is clear: the times of appeasement are over. We have to stand up and fight for our European project, dear friends. When we talk today about a better Europe, I am not thinking of treaty reform, the technology, but of David Cameron. He has campaigned and fought for Europe in recent weeks as a true statesman, and I respect that. But he, too, has made his entire political career on the back of Europe – from Brussels : he has done Brussels-bashing. No one should be surprised if people do not understand this behaviour. This is how many national politicians behave, ladies and gentlemen, and I say: stop the simple populist Brussels bashing and finally assume your responsibilities! (Loud applause) Europe needs change – no one in this House denies this – but we want to improve Europe, not destroy it. If we destroy it, there is only one alternative: the ugly face of nationalism. The people of Europe need to know that there is no reserve Europe, there is no second chance.  The referendum is clear. But there are now further results: the UK is leaderless, the parties are deeply divided, the Scottish Government is consulting on a second independence referendum, four million Britons are already calling for an election because of the lies, Johnson does not want to make an Article 50 motion and does not come up with a plan for how to proceed. And even more: the British pound is falling in value, and summer holidays are becoming more expensive for many Britons.  And it's not just Britain. In the Netherlands, the pension fund lost 3% of its value on Friday. Dutch pensioners are facing further pension cuts, and they can thank Farage and Wilders for that. At Farage's side is Putin, who is pleased with this result, and I think that says it all. (Loud applause) Britain has self-harmed with this referendum. Every European can see Britain sliding into a government crisis, being leaderless, economically damaging, and perhaps even breaking through it. That is the result of leaving the European Union. We all have to respect the result. That is why, as the President of the Commission has said, we expect a request under Article 50 and speedy negotiations. The Commission must conduct the negotiations under the supervision of the European Parliament. For both sides, a long period of uncertainty is poison. We need clarity and a clean and fair procedure.  Brexiteers have promised full sovereignty to the British. That is why, at the beginning of the further discussions, let me clarify a few rules of the game in two examples. Anyone who wants to sell their goods and services in the European Union must abide by the rules of the European internal market. The applies to Switzerland, this applies to Norway and will also apply to great Britain in the future. (Applause) The second example I want to take up is that anyone who tries to deny entry or work permits to Polish craftsmen, Lithuanian students and Romanian nurses in the future cannot expect British citizens to have unlimited access to the European Union. There are no first- and second-class citizens in Europe. Britain must also understand this. (Loud applause) I cannot say today whether the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will also vote in favour of a motion to leave the EU in the end. We will only look at the interests of the 444 million EU citizens and no longer the interests of the City of London. For me, this means that the cherry picking is over.  (Applause) But every crisis also has a chance. I would like to point out one thing: since 1989, the people of Europe have made their support for Europe in a total of 27 referendums. I would like to make it clear that we have a decision from the United Kingdom, but the overwhelming number of peoples of this continent wants to go the common way towards a common Europe and continue it. In fact, the answer we can give is relatively simple. After all, people expect only one thing from us politicians, namely: do your job at last! The Heads of State or Government are meeting this afternoon. Brexit, in my view, is a wake-up call to the unity of the European Council. If we finally stop the small-scale dispute on unemployment, refugees and the fight against terrorism, and if the leaders of Europe show the citizens that they are describing common answers for this continent, then Europe will also be supported by the people and will be led into the future. Last but not least: nationalism against Europe. I say: my homeland is Bavaria. I speak the dialect there, I live the traditions of my forefathers. My nation is Germany, and I am now feverish for my German national team at the European Football Championship. And I am a convinced European with heart and mind, because this is my continent – with all its diversity of culture, landscapes and values. I do not let anyone on this continent – any extremist – convince me that this is a contradiction. I am a Bavarian, I am a German citizen, and I am a convinced European. (Loud applause)

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker said very well: Brexit has won and we must accept this vote. With respect for the majority, however, my first thought goes to those Britons who had the courage last Thursday to choose Europe, especially the young Britons who chose the future. We are with you, we are the Europe of Erasmus, we are the Europe of culture, we are the Europe that has financed the best research and innovation projects of British universities, we are the Europe of dialogue and interreligious respect, we are the Europe of peace, which is the main value that is at the heart of young Britons and young people in the world. No referendum can break the historical, sentimental thread that binds the United Kingdom to this continent, by history and by vocation. The United Kingdom remains part of Europe which is not a treaty, but is first and foremost an ideal. And until britain has left the Eu ropean Union, this institution is and will remain the home of all Britons.  History will find the culprits of this disaster. First of all, conservative leaders and smoke sellers, who told lies to the British people. The proof is in everyone's eyes, the 'day after': they promised voters to leave the European Union, but in reality they left a field full of rubble, a constitutional crisis with Scotland, political chaos with the rest of the country, the collapse of the pound, real damage to the real economy. Now, having destroyed the country, someone would also want to destroy the European Union, paralysing the lives of these institutions. Let me make it quite clear: the European Union cannot become hostage to the current games of the British Conservative Party. And the pro-European forces in this Parliament will be able to work together to prevent this, to change, to improve and to save the European Union. The UK authorities must notify the UK's withdrawal as soon as possible and the European Commission must start negotiations after notification of the withdrawal. But I would like to invite you to think more deeply, ladies and gentlemen. The result of the referendum is not just the result of Cameron's Russian roulette, it is the result of deep pushes. Globalisation has created winners, but also losers, even inequalities, and we have been too weak in defending losers and supporting their causes. We thought that the market could solve everything, it would create magnificent and progressive fortunes and we gave up the public hand to create wealth and to redistribute wealth in a sense of equality. There has been an overpowering power of finance that has outclassed democracy, politics and institutions. We have begun to work on it as European institutions with the banking union, but much still needs to be done to reaffirm the power of democracy over the often hidden and devious powers of financial castes. We have a split continent. And we have hatred and despair that risk overwhelming everything. Europe must answer these questions. And the first answer – as Jean Claude Juncker said – is with regard to justice. And when I talk about justice, I'm talking about people, human beings, social justice, social triple A, ambitious revision of the posted workers, social pillar, fight against social and fiscal dumping, fight against global warming. Either we act in this way, or we will leave the field to a war between the poor. Justice also means getting the Stability Pact back on its hands, flexibility – Junker recalled. We must move forward, Mr Juncker! We Socialists are calling for us to go further because public and private investment must be favoured.  We need a more ambitious investment plan, and Today I say clearly that our group will oppose the translation of Eu ropean Union law into the 'fiscal compact', which needs to be radically changed. Tax justice. I did not vote for the 'fiscal compact'! Learn how institutions work. The European Parliament did not vote for the fiscal compact. Go study before you talk! – Relentlessly combating tax havens, combating fraud and tax evasion, putting into practice the measures approved by the TAXE Committee.  And then there is the great issue of democracy. Every citizen has to count. We propose that the next European elections should include the direct election of the President of the European Commission, the leader of the European Union, the Mayor of Europe. The citizens must be able to find on the card the name of the candidate for the Premiership of Europe together with the national party and the European party. This means creating a genuine European political area. We must have the courage to do these things. We were elected by citizens who believe in Europe and we must fight with all our strength, with all our feelings, with all our passions so as not to betray the citizens who have chosen us and supported us.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the British people have spoken, and they have voted to leave the European Union. Whatever our personal views we should now all respect the democratic will of the British people and work together and move on. I know there was surprise, shock, and lots of emotion on both sides of the Channel, and there will be many attempts to replay both the referendum campaign and history. Only in the last few days I have heard people say, what if British politicians had been more honest with the British people about the political dimension of the EU and the dream of a United States of Europe? What if the EU had offered more in negotiations with the British people? But that is now all in the past. Now, politicians in the UK and the EU both need to look to the future, and on both sides of the Channel we need to pause and start thinking about our negotiating strategies. Let us think carefully in the short term about the best relationship for us both in the long term. As the Presidency said, cool heads must prevail.  Across Europe there is disagreement amongst leaders about what the EU should be seeking in its future relationships with the UK. Some are saying, ‘let’s go slowly’; others are saying ‘let’s punish Britain’; and others are saying ‘we have a plan – we have an association agreement ready’. Just as in the EU there are differences, there are differences in the UK: when to trigger Article 50, whether to look for an EU-UK trade deal, whether to look for an EEA deal, or some other scenario. The EU needs to be clear and the UK needs to prepare its own plan. In the meantime, the Treaties are clear and they must be respected. So both the UK and the EU negotiators need to give the markets certainty over the timetable for negotiations: prepare your negotiating positions ready for when Article 50 is triggered, and look for a deal that is, as much as possible, mutually beneficial to both the EU and the UK. It is not the speed at which negotiations are completed, but the deal that we get at the end which is more important.  (Objections from certain quarters) Let me also say on a personal note that for centuries Britain has welcomed people from all over the world. When many European countries were mired in dictatorship and fascism, we were an open country. Today, I hope all British politicians can unite in stating that Britain will remain an open, tolerant and global nation.  (Applause from certain quarters) Regardless of how we now proceed, Britain and the EU will continue to be close partners for years to come. So now is not the time to replay the past. Now is the time to look to the future, to ensure that as we roll up our sleeves and begin negotiations, we in Britain become good neighbours and are no longer reluctant tenants. (Applause)

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by saying to the British people that it is always hard to accept a decision that you disagree with. But we have to accept it. Their choice was clear and needs to be respected. At least on that, I think the more than 700 Members here can agree. So it is my feeling that it is not so much the choice that they have made that is hard because – let’s say it – choice is the essence of democracy and of our democracy. What makes it so hard for me – and I think also for the other group leaders and for everybody here in this House – is the way it succeeded. The absolutely negative campaign, Mr Farage’s posters showing refugees like in Nazi propaganda… (Loud applause) I never thought it was possible that somebody in this House should do a thing like that. Also the lies on migration and the lies that ‘Turkey will join the Union next week’ or the lies about the GBP 350 million that would return immediately to the National Health Service and now does not go back to the National Health Service. It is that climate of fear that has been created and that negative vision that has been created that is the most shocking thing about what happened in Britain, not the choice of the people. Because the choice of the people is democracy. (Applause) And today we see the outcome of it: a multi—billion loss in stock market value and the dramatic drop of the pound – which goes down when you speak, Mr Farage, wait a little bit. Standard & Poors has downgraded the British currency and every time Mr Boris Johnson speaks, the more the British currency slips. So the Brexiteers – and they are also here in the House – and Mr Kamall will tell us that it is only a temporary setback, it is only a little glitch. I don’t know. I hope for us all that it is only a glitch. But what I do know is that we need, as fast possible, to end this uncertainty as soon as possible. That is needed now. The worst thing that can happen is to continue this uncertainty. Only the immediate invocation of the procedure for a clean separation, as foreseen in the Treaty, can end what I call the toxic climate that has been created since Thursday of last week, a toxic climate that is bad for business, bad for investment, bad – Mr Farage – for all hardworking, ordinary, decent people. (Applause) Triggering Article 50 is not a punishment. What are we talking about? For those who voted to leave, it is quite the opposite I should say. It is respecting their choice if we do so, but it is an act against the current bickering of the Tory leadership and against the selfishness of one man, who is ready to do everything – even to sacrifice the voice of 17 million British citizens and the interest of 60 million other citizens – to become prime minister of the UK – or should I say , Prime Minister of the dual kingdom of England and Wales. So we both – and I say it to the British representatives, our colleagues here – Brits and Europeans, cannot afford to be stuck in limbo. Let us be honest. Mr Kamall said that we have to negotiate and we have to prepare ourselves. Prepare ourselves? The leave camp is adrift for the moment. Lost, rudderless. Mr Kamall is voting for a leave and his colleague from the Polish delegation is asking for a new referendum in Britain. Is that the certainty we need? So we – the 27 other Members of the European Union – should not wait for a disorientated Tory party to get its act together. We should now move forward with courage and with conviction, also united towards a new horizon because there is a new horizon, a new future for our old continent. To succeed in this, I can tell you – and I will say to all colleagues – we do not need a lot of imagination. You know what we need? A healthy memory. A healthy memory to return to the big and great ideas of our founding fathers. That is what we need. Today it is very clear what that means, Jean-Claude. It means four things. We need an effective European government for the Union, and for the Eurozone. Let us make it. We need a European Border and Coast Guard to safeguard the free movement of our people. We need a European capacity to fight against terrorism and transnational crime and we need – I also think – as fast as possible a defence community, as the Americans are no longer prepared to pay for the free riders we became such a long time ago. So we need one thing. Not to start informal negotiations preparing ourselves. We need to show the people of Europe that we are capable of building a new and better Europe, a Union that can really address the many crises that it faces. In short – and I conclude – let us do for once a thing that is un-European, an exceptional thing. Let us use, for once, this opportunity, the power of this House, the cradle of European democracy, to put Europe back on track and let us not wait to do it. (Applause)

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I am very much in favour of referendums. However, I am also in favour of referendums being prepared and conducted with appropriate responsibility. For me, referendums are still one of the most democratic instruments of all. In this respect, the British referendum is more than a vote of british voters. It is very serious to be taken, it must be respected. But it is also wrong to think that the British have decided, and now they have to see what happens next, according to the motto: the EU caravan is moving on. Sedative and placebo pills do not help if the patient is terminally ill. It is about the future of the EU, whose erosion process has been significantly accelerated by this Brexit. This is also one reason why my group cannot vote in favour of the resolution that has been tabled. We do not see any thoughtfulness, no self-criticism. I think that when we talk about a memory, then we should also try to establish the historical memory, which includes the misdevelopment, the misstructures of the European Union over the last few years and decades. They are not even contemplating the deep traces of the brutal treatment – as long as it has not been – with Greece, with Spain, with Italy, and also with France, which has left many EU citizens in the memory of many EU citizens. The consequences of the deep economic and financial crisis have become felt in the minds of many EU citizens. The interference in the sovereign actions of national parliaments and governments, and even the over-the-constitution, has manifested itself. Unfortunately, it is no coincidence that there are many of the Brexiteers who fear for their jobs, social security, health care and pensions. With austerity, the EU has not shown that it wants to protect people from the effects of crises and globalisation first. And then I ask here: how blind are the members of the Council if they believe that it is precisely the promises made to Cameron last February – the willingness to make further social cuts that have been expressed there – that should motivate those very people who already feel socially isolated? The EU institutions, too – and I must include Parliament – have also allowed Margaret Thatcher's position of 'something like society does not exist' to dominate EU policy as a whole. The task of solidarity, the introduction of the Community method – crucially by Angela Merkel – is as devastating as the inability of the EU, especially the Member States, to tackle the refugee crisis together and in solidarity on the basis of the UN Convention on Refugees and international agreements. Together, the two have caused deep fears and fears, which are directed primarily against the EU. I would like to say one thing to you: if we, as the EU, had prevailed against the resistance of the British elite in particular, and had just pushed through the demand for 'equal pay for equal work in the same place', then this combination – social fear of relegation and fear of refugees and migrants – would not have happened at all! Mr Farage, I would like to thank Mr Farage for his No matter what appearance you want to create, your campaign has never got past a bloated but small campaign. The problem is that parts of London's political and economic elite have sat down and thought they could impose their vision of an even more neoliberal EU. You are and remain what you were before. The story will go beyond that, except that your name is associated with something. But there will be a reminder of your campaign that has stoked fear of migrants and refugees. We also believe that it is wrong to want to punish the British for this decision. But we also want clarity. There can be no negotiations until the British government has decided and notified its withdrawal from the EU. That is another reason why we want the terms immediate and immediate to be deleted. We also believe that the majority of voters in Scotland and the north of Ireland must be respected. We cannot and do not want to let the EU out of responsibility, including as a guarantor of the further safeguarding of the peace process in the north of Ireland. This must not happen, and here we should also be responsible and in solidarity with the people of Northern Ireland. When the Council meets today, it will be all about procedural issues. We demand that the European Parliament be involved in the negotiations from the outset, not only in the decision-making process if: a contract has been concluded. And we also want the European Parliament to be involved from the outset when it comes to the further issues of EU development. It is unacceptable that action should continue behind closed doors. The first step would be to help stop this disastrous replacement of the Community method by the intergovernmental method!

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. "Dear colleagues, there are times when political time is suspended, and we have the opportunity to make a choice. In the aftermath of the Second World War, European nations had a choice. They had the choice between continuing or breaking with the principle of indivisible national sovereignty. By deciding to share their sovereignty, they have opened a period of peace and prosperity unprecedented in European history. Today, the outcome of the British referendum can bring a historic halt to the project of political integration of our continent. But should we be surprised? From Denmark to Ireland, France, the Netherlands and Greece, there has been no shortage of warning signs of our fellow citizens' growing distrust of the process of European integration. So it's time we responded. Once again, we have a choice, and that choice will depend on the survival of the European Union. We have three options. The first is the one that was expressed last week in the United Kingdom, it is that of a nationalist and- let's say, xenophobic retreat, preached by Ms Le Pen, Mr Farage, Mr Wilders, Orbon, and so many others. (Applause) To the defenders of this option, I say this: you are right, this is democratic sovereignty, so it is the ability of our democracies to freely make the choices that determine their future. But you're lying! You are lying, because who can believe that even the most powerful member of the European Union can deal alone and successfully with the exorbitant powers of multinationals, climate change, tax evasion, organised crime and terrorism, or the reception of refugees and migrants. I tell you, no wall, no wall will be high enough, nor thick enough, to isolate Europe from the challenges of the 21st century. Today, there is only a shared sovereignty. The second option before us, Mr Juncker, is the one defended today by the majority of European governments and relayed by the Commission. This option is to restrict the ability of states to carry out their public service mission through economically insane budgetary and accounting rules and by competing with their social and fiscal systems, to free up market forces - as you like to say - by deregulating all kinds of things, in particular, Mr Timmermans, in social and environmental matters, by obstinately persisting - Mrs Malmstrom - in concluding so-called commercial treaties whose main purpose is to lock up our democracies, too often preferring opacity - and I turn to the Council - for transparency in decision-making, so as to avoid having to pay the political price for your decisions.  It is this policy that has been imposed on Europe for twenty-five years. So why, Mr Juncker, why did you choose to embody its continuity? Did you not say that you would be the President of the Last Chance Commission, to you and to all the supporters of strict neoliberal orthodoxy, I say this: no, restricting states does not automatically bring back growth. No, bringing back growth does not automatically bring jobs back and reducing inequality. And, no, making the rich richer does not benefit society. It is these political choices that are the main cause of the rise of Euroscepticism, because they lead to leaving an increasing number of our fellow citizens at the side of the road. As for us, we want to be part of a third option, both resolutely pro-European , let there be no doubt about it - but at odds with this unique thought. We want the European Union to return to the roots of its project, which was to ensure peace on this continent by extending democratic freedoms on the one hand, and by lasting and shared prosperity.  I ask you, I ask us: is it impossible to ensure the viability of the euro through a genuine social and fiscal union? Is it impossible to make the energy transition the flagship project of reviving our economy? Is it impossible to ban poisons that kill our environment and organisms slowly. Is it impossible to abandon free trade treaties that only benefit the happy few? Is it impossible for Europe to once again become a home for those fleeing war, persecution and misery? Is it impossible to put our societies within the limits imposed on them by our planet? Is it impossible to revitalize our democracies with greater transparency and citizen participation? In short, is it impossible to put human dignity, that of all human beings, here and there, now and in the future, at the heart of politics? Our answer is yes, all of this is possible, provided you want it. And if the European Union knows how to make itself the instrument of this political will, it will regain the confidence of our fellow citizens. But make no mistake, time is running out. If we ignore the signal sent by the British referendum, if we misunderstand its interpretation, it will be the European project. Colleagues, Europe has experienced the worst enough to not only hope, but build the best.  (Applause)

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Good morning.  (Loud protests and heckling from various quarters)  Thank you for that very warm welcome. Funny, isn’t it, how things have changed ...

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Farage, one second please. Colleagues, a great quality of democracy is that we also listen to those whose opinions are not shared. (Applause)

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, isn’t it funny? When I came here 17 years ago and said that I wanted to lead a campaign to get Britain to leave the European Union, you all laughed at me. Well I have to say, you’re not laughing now, are you? And the reason you are so upset, the reason you are so angry, has been perfectly clear from all the angry exchanges this morning: you, as a political project, are in denial. You are in denial that your currency is failing. You are in denial ... (Murmurs of protest) Well, just look at the Mediterranean. No, no, as a policy to impose poverty on Greece and the rest of the Mediterranean you have done very well, and you are in denial over Ms Merkel’s call last year for as many people as possible to cross the Mediterranean into the European Union, which has led to massive divisions between countries and within countries. But the biggest problem you have got, and the main reason the United Kingdom voted the way that it did, is that you have, by stealth, by deception, without ever telling the truth to the British or the rest of the peoples of Europe, imposed upon them a political union. You have imposed upon them a political union, and when the people in 2005 in the Netherlands and France voted against that political union, when they rejected the Constitution, you simply ignored them and brought the Lisbon Treaty in through the back door. (Applause from certain quarters) What happened last Thursday was a remarkable result. It was indeed a seismic result, not just for British politics, for European politics, but perhaps even for global politics, too, because what the little people did, what the ordinary people did, the people who have been oppressed over the last few years and seen their living standards go down, they rejected the multinationals. They rejected the merchant banks, they rejected big politics, and they said, actually, we want our country back. We want our fishing waters back, we want our borders back, we want to be an independent, self-governing normal nation, and that is what we have done and that is what must happen. And in doing so, we now offer a beacon of hope to democrats across the rest of the European continent. I will make one prediction this morning: the United Kingdom will not be the last Member State to leave the European Union. So the question is: what we do next? Now it is up to the British Government to invoke Article 50 and I have to say that I do not think we should spend too long in doing it. I totally agree, Mr Juncker, that the British people have voted. We need to make sure that it happens. But what I would like to see is a grown-up and sensible attitude to how we negotiate a different relationship. (Cries of disapproval) Now I know that virtually none of you have ever done a proper job in your lives ... (Protests and catcalls) ... or worked in business, or worked in trade, or indeed ever created a job. But listen. Just listen ...

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Farage, please. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which With all due respect to your excitement, you are behaving in the way THAT UKIP normally behaves here in this House. So: Don't copy them. However, I want to tell you one thing, Mr Farage: your statement that colleagues here in this House would never have done a proper job – you do not have to conclude from yourself to others. That is not possible. (Loud applause)

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – You are quite right, Mr Schulz, UKIP used to protest against the establishment, and now the establishment protests against UKIP, so something has happened here. Let us listen to some simple pragmatic economics. We, between us, between your countries and my country, do an enormous amount of business in goods and services. That trade is mutually beneficial to both of us. That trade matters. If you were to decide to cut off your noses to spite your faces and to reject any idea of a sensible trade deal, the consequences would be far worse for you than it would be for us. (Murmurs of disapproval) Even no deal is better for the United Kingdom than the current rotten deal that we have got. But if we were to move to a position where tariffs were reintroduced on products like motor cars, then hundreds of thousands of German workers would risk losing their jobs. So why don’t we just be pragmatic, sensible, grown-up, realistic and let’s cut between us a sensible tariff-free deal, and thereafter recognise that the United Kingdom will be your friend, that we will trade with you, we will cooperate with you, we will be your best friends in the world, but do it sensibly and allow us to go off and pursue our global ambitions and future. (Applause and loud catcalls)

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, yes, my dear colleagues... Why are you getting so upset? Look how beautiful history is when freedom is played with the powers in place and triumph, carried by the will of a people.  The vote of our British friends for the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union is by far the most important historical event our continent has seen since the fall of the Berlin Wall. It's a signal of freedom sent to the whole world. It is also the cry of love of a people for their country. The British chose a path that some claimed to be closed forever, and you were one of them, for that matter. To those who have consistently proclaimed the irreversibility of the European Union, the British people have made a scathing denial. This is a resounding victory for democracy. It is a slap in the face to the proponents of a European system increasingly based on fear, blackmail and lies. Your cries of gold, and thank you for giving an example of it since earlier, your threats of apocalypse, the price of your purses, the British have had nothing to do with it. They sat on it sovereignly, leaving you to your bitterness and overrated astonishments. Because, deep down, what are you surprised by? For decades, the European Union has been built against the peoples of Europe: the French and Dutch referendums trampled in 2005, the Irish being ordered to revoc after their rejection of the Lisbon Treaty, the Greeks forced to give up their referendum against austerity and who were imposed in the most violent way poverty in perpetuity.  The British people have just committed the ultimate sacrilege: they have broken the chains that linked them to the European Union, erected in religion by its propagandists. So, inevitably, when we blinded us for decades, implementing absurd policies that have resulted in deindustrialization, mass unemployment and mass immigration, ah! my God, it's hard to get back to reality and understand what's going on.  Propagandists of the European Union, supposedly on the left, centre or right, put away your sulky mines, put away your angry speeches and rejoice in the liberation of peoples: fully sovereign laws, real control of borders, an end to the contribution to the European Union, economic patriotism, patriotism altogether. This is a bright future for the UNITED Kingdom, which must motivate us all to build a better future! I'm already hearing crazy ideas: making the UK pay dearly to deter others from doing the same thing or, even more, burying Brexit by pushing it back to the Greek calendars. These are not democratic methods. The United Kingdom has decided. We respect his will, and that's it.  Your alternative now is simple: either you persist with your technocratic and expensive European Union with, as a bonus, the delusional projects of those who would like even more Europe, when the peoples want less. In this case, I promise you the rapid collapse of this totalitarian organization. Either you abandon the European Union in favour of Europe of cooperation between free states and sovereign nations. For my country, France, I am committed to leading it on the path of freedom, which is also the only one towards greatness.  Long live the free nations, long live the United Kingdom and long live France!

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, the people of the United Kingdom have given their verdict and their decision cannot be rewritten. They have recognised that the EU’s problems are not just imperfections and they have said ‘let us chart our own course’. This referendum represents a victory for democracy. The outcome was not one that our outgoing Prime Minister had hoped for. Yet he should be praised for giving the British people their say. For years the people of the United Kingdom have been trying to tell you of their frustrations and concerns about the European Union. You turned a deaf ear, but today you are listening. Now, though, is a time for cool heads. These institutions, despite what I have heard today, must resist the urge for the knee-jerk reaction. Our nation has not turned its back on Europe. We are not inward-thinking. We have for a long time sought a new relationship with our European allies, a positive relationship based on self-governance, free trade and cooperation, one which makes our world more secure and more prosperous. That does not make us any less European and it does not make us any less optimistic. The United Kingdom not only has the strength of character to succeed for ourselves, but also the inherent humanity to defend the freedoms of our neighbours. Let us look forward to a new era, one in which the European Union and the United Kingdom can work closely and calmly for the benefit of all our people. (Applause)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. "Ladies and gentlemen, I learned, during this debate, one thing I knew before: we must not leave our nations in the hands of the nationalists. (Applause) We must respect the nations, we must not respect the nationalists, who are not patriots, but who are anti-Europeans and non-patriots.  I would like us to learn the right lessons from what has been the news of the past week. We must not mix everything up We must not give the impression that Europe is the Europe of austerity. All governments, including those throughout history, ecological participation, have practiced the same policy. I do not accept Mr Lamberts' speech. Describing the Commission as an austerity commission, of overrated rigour, is not correct. I knew the Greens and the Greens in government. When you are in opposition, you are very strong. When you are in government, you do what others do. Don't teach others.  (Applause) The UK did not vote on austerity policies or inadequate border protection. The United Kingdom is not a member state of the euro, so the policies of the euro do not apply to the United Kingdom. The UK is not part of the Schengen area, so the UK is in control of its borders. So don't tell us stories. Stop telling us stories, Mr. Farage. You said a few days ago that you were wrong about the budgetary aspects of the British-European issue. If you had said that before the vote, I could have congratulated you, but you lied. You have not told the truth; you have restored the truth. (Applause)  I liked, Mr Farage, to argue with you. We have the same sense of humour. You have a sense of humour, I have humour, too. I very much regret that this is the last time we can debate, because you are not coming back.

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me repeat that we have no choice but to respect the outcome of this referendum, a referendum that should serve as a wake—up call to all of us. At this point in time, the answer is not necessarily more or less Europe. It is about a better Europe. It is about a convincing Europe. The Union of 27 will continue if the UK decides to leave, but it is clear that we will have to act. Our Union can only exist if it is supported by the millions and millions of citizens it is supposed to serve and to protect. That support cannot be taken for granted, so we need to work day and night to earn it. As I have just said, the outcome of the UK referendum does not mean that the threats and challenges we commonly face have suddenly disappeared. Neither does it mean that each nation will be better off acting on its own, rather than as part of a collective. On the contrary. In fact geopolitical developments underscore the need for unity. No country on the face of the earth can meet all the threats and challenges alone. To this end, Council and Parliament will have to work constructively in tackling the big issues that European citizens require the EU to act upon. As the new reality of a 27-Member-State EU looms, this should not divert us from concentrating on what the EU can do to meet today’s main challenges such as ensuring the security of our citizens, dealing with migration and refugee flows and boosting the European economy by creating jobs for European citizens. So let us make sure that we maintain our friendship. In a world that is rapidly becoming rougher and more complex, we cannot afford to be driven apart. We share global interests. So let us rediscover the simple notion that in this world our interests are converging rather than diverging. If anyone is fatigued by continued cooperation, let this be your wake—up call. As always, the Council stands ready to work with Parliament.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the tone of this debate and I do accept that emotions are running high this morning. But at times it has reinforced all the stereotypes that the British people fear about Europe and which they voted against on 23 June. Threats, bullying and hectoring will not work with the British people. What we need to do now is accept the result of the referendum and build a relationship that is mutually beneficial to all our people, a relationship which respects our decisions, but which helps us build prosperous economies, protect fundamental rights and secure peace in a world that is becoming increasingly dangerous.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Mr President of the Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to apologise to Parliament for leaving the debate now. Mr. Timmermans will be happy to stay here – at least he says that he would like to stay here. I have a meeting with the British Prime Minister. As I am respecting British democracy, I have to go.

name: Marcel de Graaff
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – June 23, 2016 was a historic day. A fantastic day in the history of Europe. The liberation of Europe has begun. The United Kingdom celebrates. The EU, the evil Union, is losing an important Member State. It is the beginning of the end of this failed project.  This Union is playing dirty with the electorate. A self-enriching elite is running this Union at the expense of the peoples of Europe. The british people's ruling says that sovereignty must return to the Member States. Not just in the UK, but across the EU, voters want their sovereignty back. The process of dismantling this evil Union must begin as soon as possible.  We must therefore immediately stop further political, economic and financial integration of the EU. There must be immediate restoration of national borders. The United Kingdom is and is in charge of its own money, its own borders and its own laws, and now we are demanding the liberation of the other Member States: of the Netherlands, France, Italy, Poland, Romania, of all the enslaved peoples of Europe. And I say To Mr Juncker: get out! He failed to keep the UK in and failed to bring back EU regulations as agreed. Juncker, get on with the rest of your Commission! A new Commission must dismantle this evil Union in an orderly manner.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the London stock market is rallying strongly this morning. It is now 12% up since its February lows. Sterling is weak, but then it started declining from July 2014, and the Prime Ministers of Australia and New Zealand are now vying for who can be the first country from outside the EU to do a trade deal with the United Kingdom. Things are looking pretty good. The only upheaval is political upheaval, where we have seen a Prime Minister resign and indeed the British Commissioner, Lord Hill resign. I think they have both done so for the right reasons. You never know, we may be getting rid of a Labour Party leader as well. But upheavals in politics can actually be a very healthy and a very good thing. I got into politics because our political class in Britain led us towards a European political project. So, if that result last week sweeps a few of them away, so be it. But I am looking forward next year to celebrating our independence day on 23 June. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Alyn Smith
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I represent Scotland within this House, and whilst I am proudly Scottish, I am also proudly European. (Applause) I want my country to be internationalist, cooperative, ecological, fair, European. And the people of Scotland, along with the people of Northern Ireland and the people of London, and lots and lots of people in Wales and England also, voted to remain within our family of nations. I demand that that status and that esprit européen be respected. Colleagues, there is a lot of things to be negotiated, we will need cool heads and warm hearts, but please remember this: Scotland did not let you down. Please, I beg you, chers collègues: do not let Scotland down now. (Loud and sustained applause)

name: Martina Anderson
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, MEPs like Diane Dodds and Marine Le Pen would say that we in the north of Ireland are bound by a UK vote. We say we are not and, like the previous MEP, Mr Smith, we asked you to respect our vote. We stand by the vote of the people of the north of Ireland just like Scotland, which voted remain. (Applause) We accept, we respect and we will defend the wishes of the people of the north of Ireland. However, if English votes drag us out of the EU, that would be like: ‘Britannia waives the rules’. There was a democratic vote. We voted to remain. I tell you that the last thing that the people of Ireland need is an EU border with 27 Member States stuck right in the middle of it. (Applause) You and the EU have supported our peace process and I ask you to continue to do that. Sinn Féin worked for a strong remain vote on the basis of another Europe – a more social Europe, a more democratic Europe – and clearly I say to the Commission and to the Council that you are not listening. You fail to realise the depth of opposition among the ordinary people to their anti-democratic practices and anti-social policies. These social policies and practices must change if the EU is to survive. You have to listen to that, but I ask you to please respect the vote of the people in the north of Ireland. They voted remain. (Applause)

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I will be very brief. At the end of this debate I want to make an appeal to the Members present here to now send a strong message to the European Council and to European citizens, and the best way we can do that is to vote massively in favour of the resolution we have prepared for the session and not to start saying that we do not like this or that. What is now politically important is a massive vote in favour of that resolution. My last thing will be to say to Mr Farage to say that I am shocked. Mr Farage, you are presenting yourself here as a defender of the little man and the hard worker while you have an offshore financial construction. I do not think that all citizens in Britain have offshore financial constructions. But, okay, let us be positive. Finally we are going us to get rid of the biggest waste in the Union’s budget that we have paid for 17 years. Your salary. (Laughter and applause)

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I must say that I am disappointed with the debate. It has become a very bad thing when it comes to Brexit, very bad, very dangerous, but not for The United Kingdom, because it will certainly cope and it was not necessary to shed these crocodile tears over the hapless British people. It has become a bad thing and dangerous for us, for the European Union. This is one of the worst things that has happened in the history of European integration. Meanwhile, what's going on? You play the same spectacle that is played here regularly. The same words, the same contorted faces, the same insults, only perhaps even greater. I'd rather want to listen to something else. What have we done wrong, what have those who lead this Union done wrong, what has the European Commission done wrong, and how does it hope to fix it, what has the wrong majority that governs this Parliament done? Because the fact that you recreate this old song, that nationalists are to blame, that chauvinists are to blame, that nationalists are to blame, means that you do not accept any witness of reality at all. Whatever happens, you repeat the same thing all the time. I would like to know what will happen next, because things look very dangerous. It is said that man is the only living being who can draw positive conclusions from his own mistakes. This is a general truth, but after today's debate, I wonder whether this truth also applies to those who govern the European Union.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Farage for one thing. I cannot whistle, and even if I could whistle, I would never have allowed myself to do so with regard to colleagues and anyone, but I have to say one thing to you: you have not done the good of your country and history will prove it. Unfortunately, history will prove it! This is not a time of controversy, of exploitation, it is an important historical step. We need clarity. It was wanted by some Brexit, Brexit was it? Now you don't understand why it's being handled.  Democracy wants a result to be taken note of and noticed, once again can we allow ourselves to be conditioned by the internal games of the British Conservative Party? Is it not notified why we have to wait for the Tories party congress? It is absurd, shocking, 52% of British citizens who voted for Brexit should rebel. Now it is clear that there are those who want to take advantage of this vote to destroy. We are on the opposite side, and we are in good company. We are in the company of the Christian Democrats, the Liberals, the Greens. Of all those who want to change and save Europe. We have indicated what needs to be done immediately and we call on the European Council to take account of our demands. But let us also look to the future, and in the short and medium term, let us think of a convention that is open to the citizens. So that with the citizens, not the brussels elite, we can define the guidelines for a stronger process of political integration, involving the establishment of a European Treasury and Finance Minister, a more appropriate budget, common defence and security policies, the fight against terrorism, a European FBI, common immigration policies. Here we have clear ideas! We want to do these things, soon and in the medium term, and we want to be united in doing these things, even overcoming our remaining distinctions, but which at the moment must make way for a common effort to save Europe. That is our position and we will pursue it with great firmness.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that this has been a very, very good debate in the European Parliament today, because it has made it clear to two sides: firstly, what a challenge we are facing. It is hardly worth commenting on Mr Farage, because it is not even known whether everything he claims today will be true in two weeks' time. That is why it is hardly worth commenting on. Le Pen is the best example. She has made it clear that she does not actually have an answer to the uncertainty that exists in the UK. I think she feels for herself that the French realise that Britain has the bigger problem and not France or Europe. I think she feels for herself that her arguments are running out. But that is one part of the debate. The more important thing, in my view, today was that we in the European Parliament have made it clear: we stand by this idea, we want to take this idea further into the future, we stand by the European project, and we ask – we ask you – that the European Council this afternoon and tomorrow morning should not argue internally, not discuss it internally, as we have seen in recent years. , but sends out a powerful signal that the 27 believe in the future of Europe and continue to build on this Europe.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: At the end of the debate, four motions for resolutions were tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – First of all, we must respect the determination of the british citizens and the European Parliament must start negotiations with the United Kingdom as soon as possible. Waiting and months of uncertainty can only lead to even more instability and insecurity in the European Union. The Council is to approve the Commission as a negotiator on the part of the EU on the implementation of Article 50 of the EU Treaty. The President of the Commission must hand out the UK Commissioner's portfolio as soon as possible. The Treaty of Lisbon must be fully implemented and revised. In my opinion, the triggering of Article 50 is particularly important in the negotiations to agree on the relationship between the shrinking country and the European Union. Whether it be contracts similar to those in the case of Norway or Switzerland, or trade barriers, or perhaps in the worst and least likely case, the UK will lose preferential access to the European Union market will restrict the free movement of capital and people. What is clear is that the decision taken will not only lead to trade and financial ties between the UK and the European Union, but will also depend on the cost of leaving the EU, the direction and intensity of migration. At the same time, the Decision of the United Kingdom has shown that we need to think about what led to the outcome of the referendum and how we should reform in order to increase the satisfaction and confidence of Europeans in the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The results of the referendum should prompt us all to ask ourselves what is behind it. Reflection and self-criticism should be the first reactions of a responsible parliament, while it seems that they are being replaced by haste in punishing the British and kicking them out of the Eu ropean Union.
