The referendum is a final wake-up call, which has sounded that we need to conceive of a different Union, more social-conscious and inclusive, linked to the needs of the weakest and supportive within it. The resolution before us does not, however, contain any real self-criticism. We must begin to listen to the citizens and make the European Union a community from which no one wants to leave and not an area in which those who try to make their dissent feel punished.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. – The British citizens have decided to leave the EU and this is respected by all. To date it has proved that the EU is fully united and strong to manage the new reality. Calmly and resolutely, they asked British leaders, respecting their decision, to immediately move their withdrawal process, as defined by EU rules and European institutions. Of course, the European Union must immediately address the small and large problems faced by European citizens. To shift towards a better Europe and to deepen its integration and strengthening. The EU must also shed light on its positive policies and the benefits it brings to peoples, citizens and states. The EU is not just about problems and difficulties. We support the EU, the European Idea, because this is the historic responsibility of all of us who are in the European Union, and by strengthening a united Europe we are shielding the future of our country and safeguarding the future of our children.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The decision to leave the UK is an event of enormous political significance. It represents a major change in the process of European capitalist integration and a new level of struggle for those who fight for a Europe of workers and peoples.  The British people have sovereignly decided the destinies of their country. This must be respected, especially since this referendum took place in a context of huge and unacceptable pressure and blackmail, particularly from large transnational economic groups and large financial capital, as well as from organisations such as the IMF, the OECD and the EU itself. This result is thus also a victory over fear, inevitability, submission and catastrophism.  Not ignoring the many motivations that were present in the call for this referendum and in a campaign driven by reactionary elements and open political manipulation – which we fight and reject head-on – the results of the referendum unquestionably express a rejection of EU policies.  This referendum should be seen as an opportunity to confront and solve the real problems of the peoples, questioning the whole process of capitalist integration and opening a new and different path of cooperation in Europe, social progress and peace.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. – The UK's exit will make Europe poorer, and long and complicated negotiations on exit are to be expected. The 27 now have the task of regaining confidence in the EU and, in line with citizens' expectations, prepare meaningful European reforms. Self-criticism must be exercised, a misguided immigration policy, which has been a key element of the British campaign, must be respected, the principle of subsidiarity must be respected, well-timed and realistic responses to European crises must be found, and the EU must be better aligned with citizens' expectations in all areas. These content challenges must be addressed first and foremost. Citizens' trust can only be regained if the leaders of the Member States and the EU institutions face criticism from the Union, learn lessons and take political responsibility. As always, the Fidesz-KDNP delegation in the European Parliament will seize all possible means to ensure that the opinions and interests of Hungarian citizens are displayed at European level and draw attention to the necessary changes.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The bad for The United Kingdom and the bad result of Thursday's referendum showed us two things. Firstly, the rhetoric used for years by many Member States to portray the Union as guilty of all kinds of difficult and socially unpopular decisions is starting to have a negative impact. Secondly, the referendum showed how effectively populists can manipulate citizens by stoking negative sentiments and passing on false information. However, I hope that we will be able to turn this difficult situation into positive action at the moment. First of all, we must remind citizens with determination how extraordinary the European Union is as a guarantor of security and prosperity. Moreover, on the example of the UK referendum, we can show, by eye, what methods populists use, where already the day after reaching their goal, political promises turn out to be misunderstanding and untrue.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – The referendum clearly underlined that the UK is made up of different countries. The result in Scotland, with all local authority areas voting to remain, could not have been more of a contrast with England and Wales. We voted to remain, as an outward looking, open and inclusive country, voted to protect our place in the world’s largest single market and our freedom to travel, live, work, study and retire in other EU Member States. Yet now we face being taken out of the EU against our will. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon shows exemplary leadership, declaring her determination to explore every possible avenue to ensure that Scotland can continue to benefit from the single market, and the many other gains that voters in Scotland want to retain with our EU membership. As the First Minister has pledged, the SNP Government will accelerate talks with the EU Institutions about Scotland’s place in the EU. The resolution which we will vote upon shortly was drafted in haste, and is unsatisfactory as a result. This Parliament ought to consider more carefully our response to the democratic result of the referendum, with particular attention to the remain majority in Scotland. As democrats, we must help find a way to deliver what Scotland’s voters want.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The result of the Brexit referendum fundamentally shapes not only the future of the United Kingdom, but also that of the European Union. It is therefore important that the process is done quickly and in the most peaceful way, so that we can prevent the grievances that divide Europe. We call on the Commission and the Council to do everything possible to preserve and adequately represent the achievements of free labour flows for European citizens working in Britain. The result of the vote is also a signal to the European community: a stronger, more democratic, more transparent Union must be created, with credible responses to the problems of the democratic deficit, the cumbersome operation and the refugee crisis. Hungary is whether he can participate in this process is a key issue for the public. If our country is left out of stronger integration, which is no longer primarily an economic issue, we will face not only the economic backlog, but also the resulting democratic impairment. Even Britain, which has a much greater economic weight than our country, was forced to post a very heavy economic loss on the first day after the vote. The weakening of European cooperation can lead to increased social and political conflicts within Europe and economic weakening. Since no responsible political force in Europe can wish for this, political communication that desibases Brussels in a populist way must be stopped immediately. Instead, we must create a better Europe to defend and fulfil our common values.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I take note of the British decision to leave the European Union. This rejection must lead us to ask ourselves the right questions in order to give European citizens the real answers. Thanks to the European Union, France enjoys monetary stability from which it would be deprived if it were alone. Our SMEs are finding opportunities in a large pool of 500 million citizens. Our students can freely study with our neighbours. All of this is very valuable.  But the crisis in Europe remains deep and serious because Europe needs meaning and direction. The British referendum offers an unprecedented opportunity to reopen thinking about its future. Europe needs to be re-founded. It must move away from the bureaucratic debate and into political dialogue. It must be even more at the service of citizens and their aspirations. Renovating Europe also requires the need to give it back a pilot, who can only be Franco-German. But François Hollande's five-year term has killed this alliance.  Leaving Europe will have a definite impact on the United Kingdom and on all member states, but we are forcing us to move forward. To not reform Europe would be to sentence it to death. That is why we need to get back to work quickly.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I deeply regret the tone of the debate in this House: there are plenty of threats and self-criticism. We must respect the will expressed in the referendum and not oppose right-wing nationalism and populism a cosmopolitanism that defends the same xenophobic and reactionary policies. Or is it not the case that the EU is sheltering expulsions of European citizens between Member States, while militariating its borders and refusing to host refugees from the wars it encourages in its neighbourhood? Or is it not true that the neoliberal policies you are defending are the main cause of the erosion of the living conditions and social rights of the European population? It is these policies, the responsibility of which is shared between the Commission and the governments of the Member States, that have led us to a situation in which peoples no longer conceive of a common political space, forced to compete with each other in an integration made by and for the market. Lack of democracy is the real core of a problem that, unfortunately, they refuse to face.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - Uk citizens have decided to leave the European Union. This is a major blow for both the UK and the EU. The consequences of such a decision are already looming: distortions in financial markets, the fall in the pound, the rise of populism. I regret such outcomes, but the will of the citizens must be respected. The UK has its way now. The European Union must remain united, the aim is to continue to build a stronger and better European Union. This is a message to everyone: we need to bring Europe closer to the citizens. We need to communicate more clearly the values of the European Union and what the EU means in the daily lives of our citizens.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – Britain voted to leave the EU. Negotiations to exit the Union must begin as soon as possible. It is the decision of the British people. I regret this decision, but I respect it and it must be implemented as such. The confusion due to the postponement of the activation of Article 50 on withdrawal from the Community bloc favours the increase of populist tendencies. Confusion is a negative element, which can cause problems in both the UK and the EU.  I believe that political will and unity are now needed. The founding principles of the EU must remain solid. Free movement cannot be called into question. The 27 Member States must speak with one voice. I do not think that we can now speak of Member States with more integration speeds or Member States that represent the core of the Union. That is why I will vote against the European Parliament resolution on the UK referendum.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – We regret the result of the referendum on the UK's membership of the EU, but we must respect it. It is also in the interests of the island nation and the European Union that the exit negotiations begin as soon as possible and that the United Kingdom leaves our community in an orderly way. After Brexit, we must not allow Europe's Eurosceptic, extremist parties, instigent in a British referendum, to hijack the European project and to campaign against the Union based on misleading data and arguments such as the British one. Countering such a domino effect is the main task before us, pro-European politicians. In the campaign for Britain's membership of the EU, the Brexit camp successfully convinced voters that the EU only serves the rich. We must demonstrate that the EU is capable of ensuring the rise of European citizens and reducing inequalities. To do this, it is essential to kick-start economic growth and to develop the economy. We cannot allow European voters not to feel safe in the EU. If there is no common security policy, Russia poses a greater threat in Europe's immediate neighbourhood. Without a common EU border guard, Europe will be unable to cope with the refugee crisis. We therefore need a common defence policy and a common migration policy as soon as possible! The history of the EU is a series of political crises and responses. I am convinced that, even after the current crisis, European integration will continue to be stronger.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - Britain's decision to leave the European Union opened the way for a new crisis in the EU and, on the sidelines of the four crises so far, the refugee crisis, the strained relations with Russia, the terrorist crisis and the economic problems, another major problem, and now on an uncertain scale, was added. This will have an impact on the economies, policies and security of both the EU and Britain. The 27 EU member states must be extremely balanced in order to avoid the domino effect of the British referendum. Regrettably, too many memories are short and the fact that, thanks to the EU, peace has been left behind by the emotional problems of the day. Now, however, this peace guarantee has also been hit. The EU must now think in a balanced way about how to bring the EU closer to its citizens, to ensure the promotion, stability and sustainability of the EU's common values, and to turn the EU into a functioning community capable of actively, quickly and effectively addressing the crises that hit it. Britain, on the other,must decide as soon as possible how to move forward in the circumstances in order to minimise the period of uncertainty.

name: Carolina Punset (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Let a historic member country decide to blow up the European Union's project is against the but of time. In the 21st century and in a global world, the union of Europe's future United States remains hope in the face of the disenakrote between nations and the armed conflicts that ravaged us over the past century. Despite the deep sadness that the UK's decision to leave the European Union has increased in most Europeans, this event must be used to recast, reform and relaunch the project that has given the citizens of our continent the greatest period of peace and prosperity in recent decades. As for the roadmap to follow, it is clear that if they have decided not only to jeopardize their country's unity and solidarity, but also to dynamit the European one, let us try to counter this danger with a fast and painless exit from the United Kingdom for both sides. Any dilation can cause contagion effects in other countries with populist movements as well as greater instability and economic uncertainty.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I will support the joint resolution on the decision to leave the European Union following the result of the British referendum, because the citizens have made their choice democratically and we must respect it.  However, in the interests of the integrity of the Union, we call for the rapid opening of the withdrawal procedure, as stipulated in Article 50 of the EU Treaty. The British authorities must assume their responsibilities and the institutions must negotiate a new relationship with the United Kingdom, in the interests of the Union. Brexit must be turned into an opportunity to reform the European project to refocus it on citizens' concerns. It is necessary to strengthen and improve the functioning of the Union in order to make it intelligible and relevant to the citizens. It is imperative that the European Union come out of this ordeal with its head held high, at the risk, if not, of starting the crime advocated by the Pro-Brexit British camp. We must move towards a more federal Europe giving a greater place to the European Parliament. We need a real policy of recovery, but also and above all a social policy that allows the citizen to be reconciled with the European project.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Friday was the saddest day in the history of European construction. British citizens voted for Brexit and while it's hard for us to understand, we have to respect the referendum result. Unfortunately, it was populism and misinformation that influenced this outcome, and it is a pity that a political leader's ambitions for power have led to the economic and political instability that Britain is now going through. I am concerned that xenophobia and racism are on the rise in the UK and that both European citizens and non-European migrations can be victims of marginalisation and racial hatred.  Europe faces two choices: to become stronger or to begin its collapse. We must not forget the international context, the instability in the east, the terrorist threat, and I believe that only a united Europe can face these challenges. The European project has brought prosperity, peace and stability to all of Europe and, at this turning point, we must bring Europe closer to the citizens and fight for a strong Europe.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – The EP's decision to leave the EU resulting from the UK referendum was convened very quickly and all MEPs were mobilised in a short time. It is a pity that president Schulz did not convene the EP so quickly a year ago, when a million migrants were flowing uncontrollably through Europe. Perhaps the referendum in Britain would have turned out differently. The UK referendum has set the mirror for EU leaders to take a deeper look at what we are doing wrong and how to give hope to the people of the EU for a better and safer Europe. In her speech, the representative of the EU-President of the Council of the Netherlands, Mrs Hennis-Plasschaert, very precisely named the reason why the British want to leave the EU and why people are disappointed with a common Europe. It's a "bureaucratic monster" we've succumbed to. On the other hand, we must realise that we need a united Europe in the fight against terrorism, radicalism, migration. On the contrary, Mr Juncker is still dreaming and, in his words, 'one wing has fallen off, but we will fly on...' they're out of the reality of today. He forgot to say that we were flying, but in great turbulence and in great dissatisfaction with the PEOPLE of the EU. Eu reform is now a priority if we want to leave Europe prosperous, peaceful and secure for the younger generations.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – Brexit has cut deeply into the perception of the future of the European Union. The days after the referendum show a picture of confusion, even misunderstanding, and the question of what it really was about hangs in the air. It has emerged that many did not even know what they were really talking about and that by submitting their vote they were deciding the future fate of entire generations. I believe that space should be given, above all, to the constructive dialogue that Europe desperately needs in this situation. The resolution adopted by the European Parliament wants article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon to be activated as soon as possible, although it is clear that only the British people themselves can do so. The text should take into account the real situation and be much more looking to the future. We need clear commitments for radical changes to the EU's continued action, which must go back to and put citizens at the heart of their action. It is true, however, that Britain is not going anywhere, it will still be somewhere between 33 and 34 kilometres, as far as the closeth of the British Isles and mainland Europe measures, and will not move an inch forward or backward. But he can go far away with understanding democracy, popular will and the conception of the referendum as the broadest instrument of respect for the people's will.

name: Sergei Stanishev (S&D)
text: in writing. – I deeply regret the result of the UK referendum but the democratic decision of the people of the UK should be respected. However, we’ve seen politics at its worst. The initial champion of this referendum, PM Cameron, leaves a legacy of a divided UK and a divided EU. To overcome the uncertainty we face, the departure process should begin immediately by triggering Article 50 TEU. This is the least Mr Cameron owes to the citizens – to demonstrate a bit of responsibility, to honour both his commitment made prior to the referendum and the will of the majority of the voters. The UK will remain a key friend and partner to the EU. The nature of our future relationship has yet to be determined and it will inevitably require a huge amount of time and effort. It is therefore essential that this process starts rapidly so that we can focus on other immediate challenges. The apparent disappointment of citizens with the EU, being exploited by the populists, is rooted in years of conservative, austerity-only policies. Europe now needs a new vision. European Social Democrats will offer an alternative – an agenda of progressive reforms to restore Social Europe, economic growth and social justice.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – In the light of the history and the situation, I declare that the referendum initiative by the right-wing British Prime Minister was an irresponsible, narrow-minded, self-serving adventure that put his own stay in power ahead of the future of his nation, which is already worsening his country's economic and political situation and reducing his international space. If the Brexit drama does make us hope for something positive about Europe: the political sin of his British colleague may encourage orban or any other European leader in Hungary to be more sober, or any other European leader who would like to put his own aspects of power ahead of his nation's interests into anti-European, nationalist adventures. Now, coming from the first shock, the EU institutions must do their u ubi d'edit to make sure that, based on the political lessons of the British referendum, a new beginning can be opened as soon as possible towards a more solidarity-based, more effective EU that finally fulfils the idea of a social Europe. In this context, I would understand if, in this context, the truly democratic leaders of the EU were to be completely satisfied and repelled by the minework of selfish, nationalist national politicians like Orban, who are hampering joint crisis management. I am convinced that, precisely with the swift and purposeful measures taken in the wake of Brexit, the READY Member States of the EU will soon be able to take a path that can lead to a modern Union that strengthens economic prosperity, social justice and the global weight of Europe. The most urgent, however, is the effective management of the EU's current interdependent crises, based on truly unity and Community solutions.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In Thursday's referendum, a majority of British citizens voted in favour of their country's exit from the European Union. There is therefore no doubt that any Brexit resulting from this result will have a significant impact on relations between the countries of the Old Continent and the United Kingdom in the future. I very much regret that this has happened. However, nothing happens for a reason, and the fault always lies on both sides. The Union is not an ideal organisation, it is still struggling, for example, with an over-regulation and bureaucracy. More addition, the growing "socialisation" of the Community is undermining its competitiveness in the global market, including the ambition of the middle class and strengthening claims in society.  There are also many reservations about individual EU policies, such as an extremely restrictive climate policy or a wasteful agricultural policy. However, I believe that the continuation of the European integration process should continue to be supported, because it brings real benefits to millions of Europeans every day. The Union must not fall into a marazm, but vice versa, it must make an effort for reforms that improve its functioning.  It is also extremely important to promote and perpetuate the fundamental values on which the Community is based. Only in this way will it be possible to take care of the future of Europe.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The British finally said no to Europe. It is of course a failure, but it can become an opportunity. A failure, because the European project as it is no longer convinces the crowds; a failure also for David Cameron who, in order to get re-elected, opened a Pandora's box that he never managed to close. But it is also an opportunity: to start a new job on a good basis, by profoundly reforming the rules of operation and the European institutions, with the Member States really motivated by the project, and avoiding proposing a Europe à la carte: a Europe that works and responds more effectively to the expectations of the citizens. This will require a profound questioning! Finally, after hearing their speeches, if Nigel Farage and Marine Le Pen ever enter the history books, it will be next to the definition of the word "populism".

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – I regret that the British people have decided to leave the European Union. Of course, we all hoped it wouldn't happen. We were aware that the decision to make or against would not be rational, but emotional. That is why the outcome was impossible to predict reliably. This decision is not only important from an economic point of view, but is, above all, a symbolic message. Initial reactions in financial markets suggest that exit will not go away without consequence. Not for the EU, not for Britain, which by all estimates will be the big loser of this decision. But there's no going back. That is what the British people have decided, and we must respect that decision. What I was pointing out before the referendum was that Britain is not just London City and that the will of the people cannot be underestimated. What will happen to the European Union? We'll see that in the next few months, years. We need no more Europe, we need a better Europe. a Europe that respects the will of the people and responds to their demands. a Europe that is able to detect and respond to real problems. europe, where rights and obligations are part of the same package. The British referendum was a serious reminder that it is not in itself a way for the European Union to stay for good.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I am shocked by the words of Manfred Weber (CSU) in plenary today, which confuses the EU Parliament with the Bavarian beer tent. Weber no longer comes up with a flat-out policy against his political competitor. Weber and the European Christian Democrats have not understood that EU chauvinists like them have only just stird up anger at Brussels. Instead, they continue their undifferentiated eulogy towards the EU, calling even faster for a political union and denying the existence of national interests. Establishment politicians like these are responsible for the fact that the first state is now leaving the EU. We urgently need a reversal and a Europe of diversity that is democratically built from below, is subsidiaryly organised, allows for a cross-border market economy and allows for competition.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union is a project that needs clear leadership and the involvement of all Member States. The UK's decision is therefore a retrograde step, and the lessons to be learned from this are clear. A warning to politicians should be the attitude of Prime Minister Cameron, whose wave of populism has come to power and subsequently stripped him of his post. This is an interesting chapter in the history of the European Union, with difficult decisions, but also clear declarations of what the European Union should look like in the future.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The British voters have decided, for the most part, that the country should no longer belong to the European Union. This decision should be implemented by safeguarding the interests and future of the European project. A transparent and swift negotiation of the exit process is necessary, following the formal request of the British Government, in accordance with the provisions of the Treaties.  The European Union will have to interpret the reasons for what happened and act. It was fear, in particular the fear of unregulated globalisation, competition in the labour market and the erosion of rights and guarantees that, exploited by populists, led to the decision of the British people. The risk of this situation being exploited in other countries exists and must be tackled politically.  The EU must therefore act and implement a strong programme of action to regain citizens' confidence in the European project as a path of peace, tolerance and response to people's concrete problems. A process that can lead to a convention that consolidates change but should not start with it. Immediate action is needed to make it happen and combat fear with smart policies focused on solving people's problems.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is voting time. I must inform you that explanations of vote on this resolution will be dealt with during the next plenary session in Strasbourg. There is therefore no time to give explanations of vote after the vote.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: – Mr President, on behalf of the ECR Group, I would like to move an oral amendment which changes this amendment so that the second part is deleted, and the words ‘based on his ineptitude, language and hostility towards the British people and others who wish to organise referendums on EU membership’ is taken out. So the only thing that remains, and on which we will vote, is the following: ‘Calls for the resignation of Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker.’.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this common motion because I reject a hasty resolution which aims solely to increase political pressure on the peoples of the United Kingdom following the EU exit referendum and which lacks any self-criticism towards the policies that explain the outcome of the vote.  We do not identify with the front that attributes to Europeanism the custody of democratic values, for in this Europe, that of perpetual austerity, that of the militarization of borders, that of imperialism and neoliberalism there is no future for the popular classes.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution. We hope that Article 50 will be activated as soon as possible and that transparent negotiations can begin as we had hoped the day after the referendum. Clearly, Eurosceptics and Europhobes are not on this line: they are in contradiction and have neither the slightest idea nor the slightest project for the future. David Cameron also announced yesterday in the House of Commons that he would replace Commissioner Hill: absolute cynicism. We ask Mr Juncker to leave the replacement without a portfolio! The vagueness surrounding the implementation of the sovereign decision of british citizens is dangerous for the United Kingdom, for the European Union as well. It must not last, nor mobilize all our energy: the time is now for refoundation.  Europe can disappear: there is an urgent need for heads of state or government to finally be up to the task at the European summit! The European Parliament is ready to take its share of the responsibility, as it said this morning.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the ultra-federalist resolution proposed by the EPP and S-D groups, which include French MPs from the ranks of the PS and the Republicans.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the first resolution, on the grounds that I preferred the text of other resolutions which would have been considered had the first resolution failed. However, I am in agreement with the principle that the process of the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union should begin as soon as possible.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK referendum has taken many by surprise. This is undoubtedly a turning point in the future of the European Union. Even if we do not agree with the decision, we need to respect the will of the people of United Kingdom and their democratic choice. I believe that the UK itself needs to respect its citizens will, come forward with its intentions and officially start the negotiations for leaving EU as soon as possible by invoking Article 50. We need to end the lingering uncertainty and come forward with a new vision for European Union. The remaining 27 Member States do not have any other choice but to act together in the spirit of solidarity and seize this momentum to reform the European project to become a stronger and more capable Union, giving more in return to its citizens.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the UK's decision to leave the EU following the referendum in the country. The EU must fully respect the will expressed by UK citizens. I believe that negotiations on leaving the EU, in accordance with Article 50 TEU, must start immediately after the formal notification is made in order to avoid uncertainty and uncertainty and to protect the integrity of the Union. The Council should appoint the Commission as negotiator and the President of the Commission should immediately appoint another person to the post of Member of the United Kingdom Commission. This situation has once again demonstrated the importance of reforming the Union and making it better and more democratic. I agree that the need to promote our common values, ensure stability, social justice and economic growth and meet the challenge of migration requires the development of economic and monetary union and the area of freedom and justice, as well as the strengthening of the common foreign and security policy.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. 'We regret but respect the result of the referendum. Everyone loses in this result, which forces both the UK and the European Union to reflect in depth. We need to get clarity from Britain quickly on how to proceed now. Citizens, businesses and stakeholders on both sides of the Channel have a right to certainty and a clear perspective. Europe must now work hard. The EU-27 must not be paralysed. More than ever, we must continue to listen to the public, explain why certain problems are best solved at a European level and achieve tangible results. We are calling for a stronger Europe, which, with existing powers, is making concrete strides and – if necessary with a core group of countries – is tackling terror decisively, securing external borders, building a socially just Europe and encouraging economic growth with extra breathing space for investment. This is crucial because it creates jobs, growth and hope for the future. Europe must show its citizens that their security and prosperity are indeed in good hands, so that people can feel at home in the EU again. That is the best antidote to the lies and the predatory politics of the Eurosceptics and opponents.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION to this Resolution because we understand that the will expressed at the ballot box must be respected, starting with the activation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union. We advocate that citizens can freely choose their future in democratic and transparent processes. Although we do not believe that leaving the European Union from the United Kingdom will lead to an improvement in the living conditions of its citizens. We do not agree that the outbound process will be activated immediately. We understand that the United Kingdom should legitimately assess when it will be prepared to start the process, and in no case should there be gaps with respect to the rules and treaties to which the country is subject. A process with democratic guarantees is one that guarantees the well-being of its citizens, of all people who live and work in the UK. We did not vote in favour because we thought it was essential that two amendments should come out which showed that it is essential to revive the European process in the light of inequalities and to defend the democratisation of the European institutions. They didn't get ahead and that's why our final vote was abstention.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution common to the main political groups, which, as usual, make common cause when it comes to denying democracy in favour of their Euro-federalist ideology. In order to put fear and threat in the policy, this text urges the United Kingdom to immediately implement Article 50, to the detriment of any principle of reality, but also with a complete lack of respect for the sovereignty of this nation! Instead of working to build a new friendship with the British, MEPs merely want to punish them for choosing freedom, and stoop to the Commission, which is the only legitimate negotiator. However, what this referendum has shown is that the EU would be wrong to continue to want to do so without the sovereign nations - the only ones entitled to the game of diplomacy - and without the peoples. Completely in denial, this Brussels EU is merely trying to save the EU at all costs. Yet the tocsin of freedom has sounded the death knell for the reign of this totalitarian Europe.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Brexit is not a catastrophe but an extraordinary test of freedom against the EU's anti-democratic dictatorship. That is why I did not want to support the joint resolution tabled by the PPE, S&D, ALDE and Green Groups, a text without self-criticism that b sinfully forgets that it was precisely the crazy EU policies applied by these groups that pushed the British people towards Brexit, policies that have consistently eroded the sovereignty of the Member States, turning the EU into a dangerous bureaucratic superstructure that serves the interests of banks and multinationals. On the other hand, I voted in favour of the ENL Group's resolution, which welcomes and congratulates the British people on the right choice towards freedom from the yoke of Brussels. I am sure that many other Member States will soon follow the path mapped out by the United Kingdom by allowing their citizens to choose to return free and independent to their own country.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The result of the referendum on the UK's stay in the EU is not what we would have wanted. I'm deeply sorry. For the whole of the Union, but mainly for the British citizens: the first consequences of Brexit have already been seen these days in the fall of the pound, in the announcements of relocations and in the lies that the promoters of the exit told their fellow citizens to break the European link.  We must regret that an event of these consequences has been triggered by the irresponsibility of the British Prime Minister. For reasons exclusively of personal and partisan interest, David Cameron has led his country to a consultation that has fragmented the UK, territorially and generationally. However, the British people have spoken and their decision must be respected. However, under no circumstances can the implementation of the mechanisms laid down in the Lisbon Treaty be unnecessarily extended. It is therefore urgent that Europe and the United Kingdom should start negotiating the terms of their new relationship as soon as possible. And above all, it is urgent that Europe reinvent itself and build with the citizens of its 27 member states a new project for the future.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it stresses in it that the will of British citizens should be respected in a swift and consistent way through the withdrawal procedure. Notes that negotiations on the UK's withdrawal from the EU under Article 50 TEU must start immediately after the formal notification. The European Parliament recalls that any new relationship between the UK and the EU cannot be agreed until an agreement on withdrawal has been concluded. Parliament calls on the Council to appoint the Commission as negotiator on Article 50 TEU, calls on the President of the Commission to appoint another person without delay as a Member of the United Kingdom Commission and to change the order of the Presidency in order to prevent the withdrawal process from undermining the management of the EU's day-to-day functioning. Calls also for an action plan to be drawn up with a view to creating a better European Union that will make full use of the possibilities of the Treaty of Lisbon and complement the revision of the Treaty.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the FIDESZ-KDNP People's Party Group, I regret the decision of the citizens of the United Kingdom. I supported the European Parliament's decision on this, together with the members of the European People's Party, because I believe that the opinion of the majority of The British people must be respected and that the remaining members of the European Union must ensure stability and the promotion of their interests. The text adopted in the resolution is the result of a compromise between the parliamentary factions and I therefore do not agree with all its elements. I miss it, and I regret that the text lacks the self-critical elements of the Union, the reasons that led to the victory of those who wished to leave. The most important of these are the Union's flawed immigration policy, frequent violations of subsidiarity by the EU institutions, a lack of functioning European solutions, delays in EU decision-making, frequent disregard for the aspects of national parliaments. I also do not think the urgent tone is right, because the process must take place in compliance with the EU Treaties and the British constitutional order. I also consider it unnecessary for the European Parliament to call on the Council to represent the Union in the procedure, since, under Article 50 TSI, the appointment of a negotiator, which may also be the Commission, falls within the competence of the Council.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution with clearly European and integrationist overs. The expressed desire to "reform Europe, improve it and make it more democratic" is an eternal Arlesian of the leaders of the European Union. As usual, it is not and will not be drawn any consequence from the message sent by the sovereign people of the United Kingdom to the Union.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking note of the british people's expressed willingness to leave the European Union, care must be taken to ensure that the withdrawal procedure provided for in Article 50 TFEI is activated as soon as possible and that negotiations on the case begin as soon as possible. The uk's next exit from the Eu ropean Union must take place as quickly as possible: despite an extremely sensitive context, the institutions cannot remain paralysed by the present situation for long. The citizens, associations and businesses are asking us to do this.  We must roll up our sleeves, taking up the great political window provided to us by Brexit to reflect seriously on the current limits of the European integration project, in order to relaunch it with greater vigour and conviction. We need a stronger and more united Europe, a Europe with the right resources and the appropriate competences to be able to act decisively on a globalised, ultra-liberal international context, which has produced enormous inequalities and injustices and which, for these reasons, needs to be fundamentally reformed. We need a Europe capable of raising its head, of a cosmopolitan, open, tolerant Europe, capable of responding, above all, to the losers of globalisation, in order to fight against the new emerging fascisms and guarantee peace and prosperity for present and future generations.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution deals with the decision of the British people to leave the European Union following the referendum held in the United Kingdom. While this text respects the will of the British to take their destiny into their own hands, it proposes, on the other hand, to speed up procedures so that the United Kingdom can get out of the European Union as quickly as possible. The aim is to deteriorate the economic situation of the United Kingdom in order to deter other European peoples from breaking the chains that bind them to the Union.  I therefore voted against this motion for a resolution which draws no conclusions from the result of this referendum and even calls for greater integration between Member States. In this context, the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group, of which the National Front is a member, has tabled an alternative proposal calling for such a referendum to be held in all Member States.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The majority of the British people voted to leave the European Union. This is a sovereign decision, while regrettable, but one that we must respect. The European Union and the United Kingdom must draw all the consequences and start the exit process as soon as possible. The resolution adopted by Parliament calls on the British Government to immediately trigger Article 50 of the Treaty. This is necessary to clarify things. The resolution also specifies that it is not conceivable to engage in any negotiation until the United Kingdom has activated Article 50. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this resolution to call on the UK to fully respect the will of the majority of citizens without further delay and to proceed with the official notification of withdrawal from the EU and, in any case, first notification and then negotiations on new relations with the EU. The EU must be able to use this dramatic event to relaunch the European project. We need to return to the roots of the European project and ensure sustainable prosperity for Europe. It is necessary to reform the Union by improving it and bringing it closer to the expectations of its citizens.  I agree that strengthening the EU's core should be central and that 'à la carte' solutions should be avoided. Europe is at a crossroads: either we realise the European dream or we go back a century giving life to nationalist pressures. An ambitious and clear roadmap must be defined and, in order to achieve it, full use must be made of the opportunities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon. Finally, I would remind you that, under the Treaties, the European Parliament's approval of the final agreement on the withdrawal of the United Kingdom will have to be requested and that Parliament itself must be fully involved in all stages of the exit negotiations.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The outcome of the recent referendum in the United Kingdom has been a shock to all of us but nevertheless the will of the people must be respected and I sincerely hope that the withdrawal negotiations will be carried out smoothly and swiftly. I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that a concrete plan for the withdrawal of United Kingdom from the European Union is needed as soon as possible. We need to act immediately to avoid uncertainty, which will not do anybody any good. In addition, the integrity of the Union needs to be protected and the remaining 27 Member States need to focus, most importantly, on how our community will function and evolve in the coming years. I am saddened by the fact that the United Kingdom has decided to leave us but we must now focus on ourselves and on our common future.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution tabled following the referendum in Britain does not present the elements of self-criticism of the status quo that the result of the referendum itself loudly demands. Mistakes are not recognised and it seems that the point is to punish the United Kingdom for voting freely. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. Since it was inconceivable that Parliament would not vote on the outcome of the British referendum just hours before the European Summit, I supported this resolution. I regret, however, that many amendments adopted in plenary, and mostly tabled by the EPP, have watered down a seemingly satisfactory draft resolution.  Any mention of an immediate implementation of Article 50 of the Treaty on the European Union has disappeared, even though the British government, for lack of a comprehensive strategy following Brexit, is now promoting inertia. Worse, David Cameron's request for notification of the referendum result to David Cameron is no longer included in the final resolution. This unpleasant sense of culpable wait-and-see is only reinforced by the rejection of certain amendments, one of which was aimed in particular at placing the Brexit negotiations under the supervision of the European Parliament. Finally, this decidedly weak text does not say anything about the irresponsibility of the European Council and its President Donald Tusk, who last February sealed an agreement for a "special status" of the United Kingdom in the EU, admittedly obsolete today, but still likely to generate Eurosceptic requests among the Member States most inclined to nationalist withdrawal.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As long as a resolution like the one adopted today takes note of the will of the people and plans to follow up, I agree. Another issue, and it is a pity that it has not been addressed, is how the EU needs to change to take account of the message it has received from across the Channel: the Juncker Commission has shown from the outset that it is aware of the problems and wants to address them, but it has clearly not done (yet) enough. A change of gear is therefore necessary and can no longer be postponed. It is a pity, however, that The British Members were able to take part in our vote and in the debate on the text we approved, while the EU gave up campaigning in the UNITED Kingdom, as if this was only a matter for the British people and not for all Europeans. We shall see what happens, but I will continue to monitor and represent the interests of the citizens who, by voting, have given me a mandate.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for resolution on the British/EU referendum.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: Written. I voted against the resolution because it calls for the UK to activate Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty as a matter of urgency and to begin its withdrawal from the EU. It also calls for the EU to change the Treaties. I believe that this is the wrong way to go. What is needed is time for reflection and leadership, not hasty decisions and even more uncertainty about where europe is going. Nor is it up to the EU to ask for the triggering of Article 50, but something that the UK must decide on without outside interference. We shall now maintain a constructive attitude and not isolate or humiliate the United Kingdom.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The unexpected outcome of the BRITISH referendum calls for an overall rethink of the Union's political, economic and social strategies. As raw as it may seem, the first step in getting the European project back on track is the ability to fully assume responsibility and consequently call others to their own. Starting with the British Government which, because of the superficial and irresponsible choices it has made, has a political duty and obligation to follow up the expression of the will of the people by making the request for the opening of the withdrawal procedure without delay and clearly. We, as European institutions, also have obligations to fulfil. It is up to us to show credibility, on the one hand, by not dispersing ourselves into unnecessary and damaging informal talks with Britain and, on the other, by concentrating all our efforts on real reform of the Union. We are launching a convention to revise the Treaties, to improve and make Europe more democratic, to relaunch our values – social justice, sustainability and growth – in order to definitively overcome the uncertainties of economic and social instability and to finally respond to the many citizens who still believe that a united Europe can represent a horizon of peace and prosperity.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I regretted the decision of the CITIZENS of the United Kingdom. I supported the European Parliament's decision on this, together with the members of the European People's Party, because I believe that the opinion of the majority of The British people must be respected and that the remaining members of the European Union must ensure stability and the promotion of their interests. However, the text adopted in the resolution is the result of a compromise between parliamentary factions, parts of which I do not agree with. I believe that the text lacks the self-critical elements of the Union, the reasons that led to the victory of those who want to leave, such as the Union's flawed immigration policy, the violation of subsidiarity by the EU institutions or the functioning of European solutions. The exit process must take place in compliance with the EU treaties and the British constitutional order, excessive urgency is not appropriate. Furthermore, it is unnecessary for the European Parliament to call on the Council to represent the Union in the procedure, since under Article 50 TSI, the appointment of a negotiator, who may also be the Commission, falls within the competence of the Council.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because after the EU referendum result in the UK we need to send a strong signal that the European project is very much alive. However, it needs to be reformed and take into consideration the needs of our citizens across the EU, particularly our families and the most vulnerable. It is of utmost importance that the European Union identifies the current challenges in order to address the current reality. More than ever before we cannot take a ‘one size fits all’ approach. We need to build a value-laden relationship which is not characterised with cosmetic changes. We need more action and less words. This is a critical moment for the EU. Citizens in all the Member States need to be at the core of the reform that has to be made. This is the time where the EU focuses more on the issues that can make a positive difference in people’s lives, more jobs, more economic growth, really addressing the issue of migration, better salaries and better working conditions, among others.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the joint resolution of the European Parliament which takes note of the sovereign decision taken by the United Kingdom to leave the European Union following the result of the referendum on 24 June. As the British have clarified their position, the resolution strongly calls on the United Kingdom to launch the notification of Article 50 of the Treaty on european Union as soon as possible in order to achieve a speedy and coherent implementation of the withdrawal procedure.  Although it must be analysed in the context of the British political context, such a vote obliges us to start a real reflection on the future of the European Union: what kind of integration do we want to promote? What reform of the institutional functioning of a Europe now at 27? Shouldn't the EU focus on the key issues that concern our citizens: growth and jobs, migration security and management, food and agriculture, climate change and energy? We are living in a historic moment of European integration, the British result must be respected but also a salutary start in the face of the lies uttered by the populists and an opportunity to correct the shortcomings of the EU.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fidesz and KDNP MPs regret the decision of the CITIZENS of the United Kingdom. We supported this Decision of the European Parliament, together with the members of the European People's Party, because we believe that the opinion of the majority of Britons must be respected and that the remaining members of the European Union must ensure stability and the promotion of their interests. The text adopted in this resolution is the result of a compromise between the parliamentary factions and we therefore do not agree with all the elements of it. We miss and regret the lack of self-critical elements of the text concerning the Union, the reasons that led to the victory of those who want to leave, such as the Union's flawed immigration policy, frequent violations of subsidiarity by the EU institutions, a lack of functioning European solutions, delays in EU decision-making, frequent disregard for the aspects of national parliaments. We do not think the urgent tone is right, because the process must take place in compliance with the EU Treaties and the British constitutional order. We also considered it unnecessary for the European Parliament to call on the Council to represent the Union in the procedure, since, under Article 50 TSI, the appointment of a negotiator, which may also be the Commission, falls within the competence of the Council.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. If I abstained on this joint resolution, it was because I would have preferred an environmental resolution to be put to a vote, so that my group could express its values, its analysis of the British referendum, and its ideas for the future. This earthquake is political. This joint resolution is above all technical. I am convinced that a political problem cannot be technically answered.  Beyond form, this resolution has the disadvantage of showing a monolithic and unsealed pro-European front. However, the repeated efforts of the European People's Party, an ally of the Socialists and Democrats in the grand coalition that leads the European Parliament, to prevent the development of ambitious social and environmental legislation are a thousand places away from the political Europe we are calling for. Proof of this is the fact that most of our amendments have been rejected, in particular on the supervision of exit negotiations by the European Parliament, which is the heart of European democracy. In the face of chaos, let us be realistic: whether it is climate, tax evasion, trafficking and terrorism, the answer cannot be found behind our national borders. More than ever, Europe is the effective response to our ills.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fidesz and KDNP MPs regret the decision of the CITIZENS of the United Kingdom. We supported this Decision of the European Parliament, together with the members of the European People's Party, because we believe that the opinion of the majority of Britons must be respected and that the remaining members of the European Union must ensure stability and the promotion of their interests. The text adopted in this resolution is the result of a compromise between the parliamentary factions and we therefore do not agree with all the elements of it. We miss and regret the lack of self-critical elements of the text concerning the Union, the reasons that led to the victory of those who want to leave, such as the Union's flawed immigration policy, frequent violations of subsidiarity by the EU institutions, the lack of functioning European solutions, delays in EU decision-making, frequent disregard for the aspects of national parliaments. We do not think the urgent tone is right, because the process must take place in compliance with the EU Treaties and the British constitutional order. We also considered it unnecessary for the European Parliament to call on the Council to represent the Union in the procedure, since, under Article 50 TSI, the appointment of a negotiator, which may also be the Commission, falls within the competence of the Council.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution, which puts the success of Brexit into perspective, is a continuation of the federalism that we have been denouncing for several years. The text aims to make full use of the Lisbon Treaty, to deepen economic and monetary union, to give the Commission a negotiating role and to defend the development of a European constitution. However, the British vote shows the disconnect between citizens and a European construction that turns out to be technocratic, ultraliberal, bureaucratic and disconnected from reality. It is not by strengthening the Commission and European integration that States will regain their sovereignty. I therefore voted against this European resolution.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution. The European project has clearly failed. On 23 June British citizens decided that their future is outside the EU and under no circumstances should the EU show vengeful tendencies against Britain.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fidesz and KDNP MPs regret the decision of the CITIZENS of the United Kingdom. I supported the European Parliament's decision on this, together with the members of the European People's Party, because I believe that the opinion of the majority of The British people must be respected and that the remaining members of the European Union must ensure stability and the promotion of their interests. The text adopted in the resolution is the result of a compromise between the parliamentary factions and I therefore do not agree with all its elements. I miss and regret the lack of self-critical elements of the text concerning the Union, the reasons that led to the victory of those who wished to leave, such as the Union's misguided immigration policy, frequent violations of subsidiarity by the EU institutions, a lack of workable European solutions, delays in EU decision-making, frequent disregard for the aspects of national parliaments. I do not think the urgent tone is right, because the process must take place in compliance with the EU Treaties and the British constitutional order. I also considered it unnecessary for the European Parliament to call on the Council to represent the Union in the procedure, since, under Article 50 TSI, the appointment of a negotiator, which may also be the Commission, falls within the competence of the Council.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution indicates the worst purposes on the future and on the attitude towards the people of the United Kingdom. It is unacceptable and demonstrative of the majority of this Parliament's choices regarding the respect (or lack thereof) for democracy and the sovereignty of the peoples.  Faced with a legitimate and sovereign decision, a veiled blackmail is waved, a kind of 'revenge' against the British people is rehearsed, on which stigmas are cast which are immense dangers in a framework in which EU policies - antisocial and disrespect for the sovereignty of peoples - open the way to the growth of the far right. The resolution aims to trigger a process of so-called 'negotiation' which, in fact, seeks to transform the realization of the will of a people into a real torture for that people and for a sovereign State, all framed by Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon.  This resolution is in the way of reality. It is a flight forward that seeks to ignore the fundamental problem that the British referendum expresses: the peoples of Europe increasingly express their opposition to the EU and its policies. Another Europe is needed. A Europe that rejects exploitation and oppression and is based on cooperation, peace, solidarity, mutual respect and the defence of the sovereignty of peoples.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. First of all, I am very sorry that the United Kingdom has decided to leave the European Union. It is a sad day for the Union, as well as for all those citizens of the United Kingdom who feel like European citizens. I voted in favour of this resolution, as the most important thing at the moment is to show the unity of pro-European parliamentary groups in these circumstances. I hope that there will be a fair negotiation during this process, but I echo the words of President Jean Claude Juncker during this plenary session: there should be no negotiation until there is notification.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution tabled by the major political groups in Parliament: after Brexit, they still do not seem aware that this European Union needs to be changed and completely refounded!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the result of the referendum in the United Kingdom, as the European project has clearly failed. On 23 June British citizens decided that their future is outside the EU and under no circumstances should the EU show vengeful tendencies against Britain.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fidesz and KDNP MPs regret the decision of the CITIZENS of the United Kingdom. We supported this Decision of the European Parliament, together with the members of the European People's Party, because we believe that the opinion of the majority of Britons must be respected and that the remaining members of the European Union must ensure stability and the promotion of their interests. The text adopted in this resolution is the result of a compromise between the parliamentary factions and we therefore do not agree with all the elements of it. We miss and regret the lack of self-critical elements of the text concerning the Union, the reasons that led to the victory of those who want to leave, such as the Union's flawed immigration policy, frequent violations of subsidiarity by the EU institutions, a lack of functioning European solutions, delays in EU decision-making, frequent disregard for the aspects of national parliaments. We do not think the urgent tone is right, because the process must take place in compliance with the EU Treaties and the British constitutional order. We also considered it unnecessary for the European Parliament to call on the Council to represent the Union in the procedure, since, under Article 50 TSI, the appointment of a negotiator, which may also be the Commission, falls within the competence of the Council.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. The vote for Brexit is a narrow, sovereign decision by the British that must be respected. To the fullest extent. For both sides. As much as I, as an offensive Brexit opponent, regret the outcome of the referendum, it is clear that the time for Britain's special role in the EU is definitely over. It is now a question of adopting the country fairly from the EU at the initiative and wish of a majority of its own citizens and of offering it a new, friendly perspective. It is up to the UK to submit the Article 50 application in a timely manner. And it is up to the EU to make an offer of negotiations immediately afterwards. Personally, I believe that full BRITISH membership of the European Economic Region – with full recognition of all four fundamental freedoms – is a fair offer. I support regional EU accession scenarios wherever a majority of citizens want them. There must definitely be no "neverendum" – that is, further renegotiation or a half-exit: there is outside. Basically, the result of that night already knows only losers. But the biggest ones will be the British themselves – although these consequences will not be felt until the coming months. Europe, too, must learn: we do not need more Europe now. We need a Europe that gives more to its citizens, delivers more!

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The shock of Thursday's Brexit vote is still deep. This was also felt in today's debate. Between the lines one could read anger and disappointment. At the same time, many have expressed hope for the European idea. 2016 is a fateful year for the European Union. We must respect the wishes of the British people. At the same time, both national and European politicians must draw the right conclusions. In the end, it's very simple: everyone has to do their job in their place. Then it is not more or less Europe that is at stake, but about making Europe smart and efficient.  The European Union must abandon its attempt to regulate the internal market with the most small-scale regulations. But then we also have to face up to more competition. I think it is right that Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has reduced the number of legislative initiatives by 50%. At the same time, we must deliver on the crucial issues. There is no need for a new constitution. People will judge us by what we implement, not by what airlocks we build.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As a prominent Brexiteer in Wales for UKIP Wales as well as Vote Leave, I am honoured and proud that the people of Wales voted against the collective might of the establishment, for Wales to leave the EU. It is now the duty of the British Government, and the Welsh Government to set aside their differences, and to now work to fulfil the will of the people of Wales and Britain. I believe that Article 50 should be invoked within weeks, and that the British Government should now start trade deals with nations like Australia, Iceland and New Zealand who have asked to be at the front of the queue. This is a new dawn. This is an opportunity for our nation to regain our Democracy fully, regain full control of our borders and decide to work with the entire world, and not just one continent. I fear that the EU and the establishment will work together to stop us from leaving. We must remain vigilant and act as the canaries in the mineshaft for the British people. Ultimately, trust the British people, they always get it right in the end!

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain from this Resolution because we understand that the will expressed at the ballot box must be respected, starting with the activation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union. We advocate that citizens can freely choose their future in democratic and transparent processes. Although we do not believe that leaving the European Union from the United Kingdom will lead to an improvement in the living conditions of its citizens. We do not agree that the outbound process will be activated immediately. We understand that the United Kingdom should legitimately assess when it will be prepared to start the process, and in no case should there be gaps with respect to the rules and treaties to which the country is subject. A process with democratic guarantees is one that guarantees the well-being of its citizens, of all people who live and work in the UK. We did not vote in favour because we thought it was essential that two amendments should come out which showed that it is essential to revive the European process in the light of inequalities and to defend the democratisation of the European institutions. They didn't get ahead and that's why our final vote was abstention.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the decision to leave the EU following the UK referendum because measures must be taken to implement it. The UK must immediately notify its exit from the European Union under Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union so that the EU can establish its roadmap. The vote of British citizens must be respected, even if the effects on them are partly negative. The challenges at the moment underline the need for a reform of the Union to make it more efficient, ethical and democratic.  I voted for the resolution so that, as a matter of urgency, the Commission and the Council will find together with the Member States the appropriate measures for growth, reindustrialisation and security. The CORE of the EU needs to be strengthened, even if some Member States may choose to integrate more slowly or to a lesser extent. It is also necessary to promote common European values and ensure stability, social justice, sustainability, economic growth and job creation.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. I support the procedure to invoke Article 50 of the Treaty starting as soon as possible. The UK people have decided and the UK Government has to act accordingly. The uncertainty for the EU as well as for the UK and its nation should be abolished.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fidesz and KDNP MPs regret the decision of the CITIZENS of the United Kingdom. We supported this Decision of the European Parliament, together with the members of the European People's Party, because we believe that the views of the majority of Britons must be respected and that the remaining members of the European Union must be stability and their interests. The text adopted in this resolution is the result of a compromise between the parliamentary factions and we therefore do not agree with all the elements of it. We miss and regret the lack of self-critical elements about the Union and the reasons that led to the victory of those who wanted to leave. Thus, the Union's misguided immigration policy, frequent violations of subsidiarity by the EU institutions, the lack of workable European solutions, delays in EU decision-making and frequent disregard for the aspects of national parliaments. We do not think the urgent tone is right, because the process must take place in compliance with the EU Treaties and the British constitutional order. We also considered it unnecessary for the European Parliament to call on the Council to represent the Union in the procedure, since, under Article 50 TSI, the appointment of a negotiator, which could also be the Commission, falls within the competence of the Council.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The citizens of the United Kingdom have made up their minds and their verdict should be respected by all. The decision by the British to leave the European Union should primarily concern European leaders about the policies pursued in the Union and the impact they are causing its people. The joint resolution put to the vote in plenary refuses to address these issues by calling for changes in the policies to be followed. That is why we voted against the joint resolution.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Brexit has disappointed and surprised many. But that is no reason for EU politicians to play insulted liver sausage sands now and to punish the British people!
