name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The UK will leave the European Union. The British people have made a sovereign choice and while we may regret it, it is a decision that we must accept and the consequences that will follow. Europe has been going through a strong period of turbulence since the 2008 crisis. But Europe's decline is not only linked to the succession of economic and financial crises, migratory pressure and the terrorist threat. It is also the result of the lack of leadership, the shortness of the Franco-German engine, the absence of a great French figure capable of influencing decisions in Brussels and restoring faith in the European project to the French. The United Kingdom's decision affects us but must also encourage us to turn Europe into an opportunity, to recognise that we have not heard enough of the concerns of the peoples and that we must propose to them a project re-founded in the economic, fiscal and social fields, in the defence of our borders and our identities, in migration and asylum policy strong enough to restore their confidence.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on the decision to leave the EU on the basis of the outcome of the UK referendum on the grounds that I believe that the exit process, the so-called "exit process". brexit, needs to be implemented swiftly and consistently, and that a new UK-EU relationship cannot be established before the withdrawal agreement is concluded. I believe that any possibility of uncertainty that could jeopardise the interests of the Union should be eliminated and that the European Parliament must be involved in all stages of the exit process.  While the outcome of the referendum was not the one most Member States of the Union had wished for, it is necessary to respect the will of the citizens and think deeply about the future of the Union.  Problems will arise in many member states, and announcements of a similar referendum in France and the Netherlands are already coming. It is uncertain whether the EU will take the path of greater unity or take the path of looser relations between members. This resolution, which represents the position of the ALDE Group, takes into account key aspects of the current state of this major problem, and therefore I support it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. On 23 June, British citizens strongly expressed their desire to leave the European Union. The European Parliament met following this historic event to adopt a resolution on the consequences of Brexit, which I supported.  On the basis that the choice of the British must be respected and acted on accordingly, the resolution calls for the withdrawal clause from the European Union to be invoked as soon as possible and for the divorce procedure to be implemented quickly. In my view, it is only after this procedure has been triggered that negotiations on the new status of the United Kingdom can begin. In the meantime, it is imperative that British representatives in the institutions are no longer allowed to get involved in European legislation. That is why Parliament has called for an internal reorganisation of the Union's institutional structure and stressed the need to reform it. I am convinced that Europe and its member states must quickly challenge themselves, rebuild a new European political project, question how it works and refocus the EU on its fundamental priorities. Without it, we risk a complete rejection of the citizens that will cause a Brexit epidemic.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. With the decision to leave the EU, the UK has made a landmark decision about its place in the world. There should be no doubt that I had sincerely hoped that the British would stay in the European Union. But a majority of the British people wanted it differently, and of course it must be respected. That is why I believe it is in everyone's interest, and especially in the British, that the formal withdrawal negotiations get under way as soon as possible. Prolonged uncertainty about the UK's relationship with the EU will damage the UK economy and could lead to real wages and mass lay-offs. However, the result must also call for soul-searching in the rest of the EU. I do not believe that what is being demanded from the peoples of Europe now is more treaty change or long talk about how we make the European Union more relevant and citizen-friendly. I think what really matters is results.  We must deliver the political solutions that Europe needs: an effective fight against tax evasion and tax havens, against social dumping and wage printing, for ambitious and binding environmental and climate targets, for strong cooperation on cross-border problems and real investment in Europe's economy that will create growth and jobs – at fair pay and on contractual terms.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must change and European leaders must take responsibility for the current state of affairs. The truth is simple sometimes, but we all know that the journey will be extraordinarily difficult. Now is the moment when we all speak in the same voice. We are talking about change and the need to return to the interests of citizens. We're talking about how we need to start listening to their needs and wishes because they've had enough of empty statements and empty talk. However, the President of the Commission talks about other problems. He says he's sorry he's perceived as a robot and a technocrat. Moreover, he informed us that he was sad about the UK's departure from the EU and that it was an emotional moment for him. Nigel Farage asked why he had come to the plenary session, but he had to watch his winning grin for the rest of the morning. I only want to know one thing - has the President of the Commission realised that it is also his fault that right-wing populists are celebrating and planning further referendums? I don't think so, and that's the problem. No one wants to take responsibility. The EU does not have a strong personality. Faced with shock, the EU finds itself without a leader capable of solving its problems. Juncker must make room.  I did not support the joint resolution because it did not deal with the main thing - who is responsible for the disintegration of the EU.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Today we have had a historic debate on the consequences of Brexit. The resolution adopted by the House calls on the British Prime Minister to present the results of the referendum and the European institutions to act as quickly as possible. I regret the outcome of the referendum, but I obviously respect the will of the majority of citizens. We are in a period of crisis for the whole Union, but we must not allow ourselves to be discouraged by what has happened. Instead, we take this result as an input to step up our efforts and continue to work together towards an increasingly cohesive European Union. It was heartwarming to hear my Scottish colleague Smith talk about his and the people of Scotland's willingness to remain in the EU. We need to think about 48 % of those who voted for Remain and we need to give a strong response and create the future of Europe with the other 27 countries, in order to have a more integrated, different Europe that is able to respond to its citizens, with more policies in common, defence, security and, above all, a foreign policy that is truly a European policy.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the joint resolution on the result of the referendum in the United Kingdom. This text is further proof that the federalist groups in this Parliament have not understood or want to understand anything. Although he stresses that the will expressed by the people must be fully and scrupulously respected (it would only be missing that), he advocates that the "European project" be "relaunched", but if other European peoples were given the opportunity to express themselves, they would rather want to revive the sovereignty, freedom and control of the borders of their countries. The spring of the peoples is now inevitable, which is why I am fighting for a referendum in France.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against Parliament's joint motion, because I believe that we must respect the outcome of the British polls and make a deep self-criticism of how European neoliberal policies have fuelled right-wing populism and xenophobia in old European democracies (both among those who advocated exit or permanence within the EU). Interference and continuity in an imperialist and neoliberal Europe are not the way.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution. The decision of British voters to leave the European Union in a referendum must only be respected, and I do not agree with the misuse of Britain's exit to further centralise the EU. In particular, I do not agree with the call for restrictions on member states' rights to choose their own level of integration ("Solutions must be avoided where states would choose their own areas of integration."). I consider this to be a push to introduce the euro in the Czech Republic, regardless of the will of the citizens in our country. Nor do I agree with the call to strengthen the EU's powers in response to Brexit ("THE EP calls for a plan to achieve a better Union based on the use of all the possibilities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon and culminating in an overhaul of the Treaty."). I also disagree with the decision to reorganise the European Parliament ("THE EP will make changes to its internal organisation in the light of the will of uk citizens to leave the European Union"), this can be read as an effort by the EP to disqualify British MEPs before the formal end of British membership. British MPs have the right to full representation before Britain ceases to be a member of the EU, and this may take two more years.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This was a referendum on Britain's future in the European Union, not the future of the European Union! From now on, Britain is on track to begin the withdrawal process. The real question for us is how to protect the interests of our compatriots on the Island. The referendum was a gamble by Cameron to save his own political career. Critics of the European Union didn't really want Britain to leave. Unfortunately, they realized it late. We are now witnessing a refusal to consume this political "victory." In practice, the UK voted to regain the right to withdraw and restrict the rights of European citizens by returning those powers to its own institutions. Bulgarian citizens, especially the young, will be put in a situation where they will not have the security and guarantees that the European Union provides.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The British have decided to take the UK out of the European Union. We must respect this democratic expression, while drawing all the consequences of this painful choice which is putting Europe to the test. The emotion passed, we must control this shock, and to do so act with clarity and speed in order to avoid any prolonged uncertainty. The UK must therefore inform its 27 European partners as soon as possible of its request for withdrawal in accordance with Article 50 of the Treaty.  The forthness of the negotiations between the European Union and the United Kingdom should be able to reconcile the interests of the EU and its citizens, without turning its back on a country that will nevertheless remain a partner with which we must maintain good relations.  Because Europe is a great idea and not just a big market, this departure must above all be an opportunity for a profound re-foundation of the EU by prioritizing a more democratic Europe and therefore close to the citizen; a Europe resolutely focused on sustainable investment, growth and employment.  This voluntary resolution, I vote for it.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the motion for a joint resolution on the UK's decision to leave the EU as a result of the referendum. In the proposal, we express respect for the outcome of the expression of the will of the citizens and reflect on the way in progress, i.e. in particular by triggering Article 50 of the Treaty, that is, by starting the process of withdrawal from the EU. However, I completely lack any self-criticism, self-reflection and recognition of errors by the Commission in particular. There is only one thing, even an imperfect provision on social policy, listening to citizens and reducing the much-criticised bureaucracy. We have no thought at all about the reasons that led the British people to vote in the referendum. At the same time, I also find it problematic that the resolution does not mention the situation of Scotland and Northern Ireland, let not at all the lies and biased information on which the brexit campaign was based. The result of the referendum is, in popular terms, a "slap in the face" to the current form of the EU. I also lack a more detailed plan in the resolution, a vision of what path to take in order to correct the historically lowest support and trust of citizens in the EU. Because of these shortcomings, I could not support the resolution and I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The UK represents the EU's second largest economy, with 65 million consumers, is important in geostrategic balance at 28 and abandons the political space that successfully aggregates the major powers that fought in the first and second world wars. The UK's departure is a loss for the EU, but it will also be a serious problem for the British, noting that almost half voted to remain in the EU, and Scotland and Northern Ireland mostly for that stay.  My vote expresses respect for the will of the British.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it sets out the way forward for the Union vis-à-vis the result of the UK referendum on their EU Membership. This cross-party resolution lays out the groundwork for reflecting on and improving the functioning of the European institutions, and ensures that the will of the voters of the United Kingdom is respected.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – In a referendum in Great Britain on its membership of the European Union, 51.9% to 48.1% of voters voted to leave the European Union, a democratic decision of the British people. The European Union will not hold any informal talks with Britain on leaving unless London formally requests to leave the Union. I believe that negotiations on the Withdrawal Agreement should start as soon as possible and should take place in accordance with Article 50(2) of the Treaty on European Union. Until a formal British exit from the Union, both the rights and obligations under Union law will apply to the United Kingdom and the United Kingdom. I also believe that the negotiations should take place in a prudent and moderate manner to ensure that the Withdrawal Agreement establishes a positive and constructive partnership between the European Union and Great Britain in the future. At the same time, however, I am convinced that the Union will put an end to this situation and will continue to be an area of cooperation, democracy and peace. In view of the above, I support the proposal.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In connection with the Council and Commission statements on this subject, the ENF, GUE/NGL and ECR Groups have submitted separate draft resolutions, as well as joint draft resolutions from the PPE, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE groups. The four-party draft advocates the early start and swift conclusion of the withdrawal process in order to prevent uncertainty that is detrimental to all and to protect the integrity of the Union. It points out that the United Kingdom cannot claim any benefit or special procedure. He recalls that under the agreement reached in February 2016 between the heads of state and government, it was finaled by voting to leave. He argues that any new relationship between the EU and the UK can only be discussed after the exit process. It also takes a position in favour of accelerating closer and deepening integration. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The referendum in the United Kingdom was, in my view, involved in an unclear and in no-see campaign about the real causes of a possible exit from the European project. However, we must respect the majority of the citizens of the United Kingdom and their desire to leave this Union on 28.  I therefore believe that the British Government should notify the Council and the Commission as soon as possible and that negotiations under Article 50 TFEU should be initiated as soon as possible. We must not let this process create even more uncertainty, and the Union and the United Kingdom must start drawing up the new relationship between them.  We have a duty to observe the European project and bring it closer to people. We must make an effort to respond to the longings of European citizens. We must never forget that this project has made peace, prosperity and stability possible in Europe. We need a Europe to and from people. We must not fall into a policy of national protectionism because together we are stronger.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The British people voted to leave the European Union. This historic vote will be remembered as the equivalent of the fall of the Berlin Wall for the USSR. Faced with this scathing failure of an EU they fetishise, the Members of the European Parliament have therefore decided to respond with denial: no, everything is fine in Europe, the British signal is only one of their ingratitude; and yes we have to continue as before.  More seriously, MEPs want to punish the British people who have had the addedcuence to challenge the European order. This resolution calls for the swift implementation of Article 50, but it is up to the sovereign government of the United Kingdom to make this decision. The treatment of the UK's exit from the EU will therefore be in the image of what this tyrannical monster has done with all the other peoples so far: brutalisation, contempt and arrogance. I vote against this resolution and say to the peoples of Europe: watch the actions of this totalitarian monster; you too may one day be the victims.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the result of the referendum on the UK's exit from the European Union. I am attached to the European Union, which has guaranteed us peace for 60 years. I take note of the decision taken by our British friends and respect it. It is motivated, among other things, by the irresponsible policy of migrant quotas, a real call for illegal immigration and the wave of mass migration that The peoples of Europe are experiencing and rejecting. I regularly oppose these choices which contribute to the disintegity of the European Union. The text calls for a speedy negotiation of the UK's exit in order to limit the legal uncertainty and uncertainty that would harm our businesses and our fellow citizens.  Finally, the resolution also acknowledges the resignation of the British European Commissioner and states that the European Parliament will have to change its organisation to take account of a return to 27 Member States.  Irrespective of Brexit, I call for the United Kingdom, which is our ally, to remain a major partner of the European Union in all areas.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that reiterates the importance for the European Union to continue working together after the referendum in the United Kingdom to leave the EU. Even though the situation is unfortunate, the UK must send the request confirming their desire to leave the EU as fast as possible in order to start the negotiations and prepare the EU and the Member States for the new context. Therefore the resolution stresses the need for the European Union to reform in order to be able to face the current challenges.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the resolution on the UK's decision to leave the EU following the referendum on 23 June 2016. The European Parliament stresses that the will of the British people must be fully and fully respected, starting with the immediate activation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU), and negotiations must begin immediately after official notification. Any new relations between the Uk and the EU cannot be established before the withdrawal agreement is concluded. Given the critical historical moment for the EU, the interests and expectations of union citizens must be brought back to the heart of the debate and the European project must be relaunched. The EU must ensure stability, social justice, sustainability, growth and job creation, overcome persistent economic and social uncertainties, protect citizens and address the challenge of migration. It is necessary to develop and democratise, in particular, the economic and monetary union and the area of freedom, security and justice, as well as to strengthen the common foreign and security policy. Reforms must lead to a Union that meets citizens' expectations.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I cannot support the resolution in this text because it is too critical of the United Kingdom. Ultimately, the vote represents the will of the British people and must be respected accordingly.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Referendum is a serious weapon and a strong expression of the will of the nation. The decision to question the views of the nation was a wise and far-sighted political move. It is therefore very important that the wish of British citizens to leave the EU is heard. The will expressed by the people must be fully and fully respected.  I believe that the reaction to the referendum result is inadequate, as are inadequate design policy decisions. What remains to be done to hear the voice of nations? The Decision to initiate the withdrawal procedure must be taken independently by the United Kingdom.  Europe must be a commonwealth of equal states. The fundamental idea of european communion cannot continue to be undermined. It is necessary to convene a pan-European Convention of States to draw up new guidelines for the European Constitution and to provide a new, true impetus for the unity of nations on the road to a prosperous Europe.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party voted against the joint resolution of the People's Party, the Social Democrats, the Liberals and the Greens on "the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU". The resolution seeks, in the context of fierce opposition and competition, to set the terms of the EU monopolies for the conclusion of the agreement to leave the EU. It also attempts, as the propaganda of the SYRIZA-ANEL government does, to present the EU, this union of monopolies, as a supposed defender of popular interests, sowing illusions that the EU can "reform, become better, more democratic" etc. The EU cannot become pro-grassroots. It serves the capital and therefore only worse for the people can be done. The working class and the other poor working classes have the only way out with their struggle to overthrow the power of capitalists and with the keys to the economy in their hands to impose in their interest the release from the EU, NATO and any other alliance of capital.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the final vote on the joint resolution on the UK's exit from the EU. This choice is due to the fact that the resolution adopted does not clearly and honestly record the real causes of the EU crisis and the changes required in the course of the European Union in order to regain the confidence of the citizens. The resolution avoids any clear reference to the ongoing austerity policies, its distorted and unilateral architecture, the growing social and regional disparities and the lack of a comprehensive and solidarity-based European refugee policy, as proposed in the relevant resolution and its amendments which unfortunately were rejected by the Eurogroup of the Left.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I am sorry for the decision to leave the EU taken by UK citizens, but their decision must be respected, so I supported this resolution on the decision to leave the EU based on the outcome of the uk referendum. The links created over the last forty years are profound and the UK's influence on the development of European society during this period is invaluable. Unfortunately, our partnership in its current form has come to an end because after the decision has been made there is no going back.  Faced with the historic decision of UK citizens that their country, after 43 years of membership of the European Union, ceases to be part of the European family and continues on its own alone, we face many challenges that we must approach appropriately. At this point we must remain "calm and determined." Disassociation should be carried out as soon as possible and within the foreseen period of 2 years. It is also worth thinking hard about the reasons that led to the dissatisfaction of UK citizens and its exit from the EU. Each new situation is also a challenge to learn something new and to come out of it better and stronger than we were. We now have a great challenge ahead of us in which we must preserve a strong and united Europe – with Great Britain as a reliable partner.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution shows the contempt that democracy inspires for idolaters of the European Union. A free people spoke at the ballot box. Its will, clear and indisputable, must be respected and implemented. The sectarian rage shown by both some MePs and some Commissioners, not least, is unacceptable. The treaties provide for negotiations to settle the details of a Member State's exit. As this possibility, by pure ideology, has never been seriously considered, the negotiation is going to be complex. All the more reason to approach it rationally, in a respectful and serene climate. That is not the spirit of the text put to the vote today and that is why I am voting against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The result of the referendum on whether or not the UK would remain in the EU did not yield the result that most of us had hoped for. The British people have democratically decided to leave our Union and this decision must be respected. With this resolution, the European Parliament is now calling for a clear and, as far as possible, rapid path in establishing the new relationship between the UK and the EU. We do not believe that further uncertainty and hesitation will benefit either the Eu ropean Union or the United Kingdom. That is why it is necessary for the British Government to activate the separation procedure as soon as possible, preventing internal instability from causing problems for the whole continent. It will be a difficult and probably painful path, especially for all those Britons who voted for Remain and who still believe in the European dream: all my solidarity goes to them. Parliament must, however, take note of the will of the majority, and the firm position we are expressing in this resolution is therefore right. We must respond to this instability by strengthening the Union and its institutions, which will increasingly have to be close to the peoples of Europe. Only in this way can nationalism be defeated.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. First of all, I take note of the desire of UK citizens to leave the EU. I believe that the will of the people must be fully respected. I support the European Parliament's resolution on the decision to leave the EU based on the outcome of the UK referendum. I am pleased that with this resolution the four largest political groups (PPE, S&D, ALDE, Verts/ALE) in the European Parliament have shown unity. It is this kind of unity that will be important for reforming the European Union in a way that makes it better and more democratic. The European Union has brought a long-lasting peace to the European continent for the first time in its history. The European Union and its single market bring prosperity and competitiveness to Member States and make Member States more influential globally. Therefore, if there is something about the functioning of the European Union that does not meet the expectations of citizens, I do not think that the solution is to destroy the project of a united Europe, but I believe that a common force needs to reform the European Union in such a way that it provides stability, social justice, sustainability, growth and jobs, overcomes long-standing economic and social uncertainty, protects citizens and tackles the challenges of migration. As Winston Churchill said, "the pessimist sees the problem at every opportunity, and the optimist sees opportunity in every problem." I was and remains Eurooptimistic!

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted in the extraordinary plenary session following the result of the British referendum, which on Thursday 23 June 2016 announced the UK's exit from the European Union. I respect the choice of the majority of British voters but stress the importance of the UK taking responsibility for the choice of citizens. In this respect, the country will have to activate Article 50 before any agreement can be reached.  The question now is: what Europe do we want? Let us have the courage to affirm our ambition: that of a strong and protective Europe. For this, it is a matter of being firm and not being dictated to by British leaders who are already beginning to realize the negative effects of leaving the EU. Pragmatism, efficiency and political will will drive a community of destiny ready for the challenges of the 21st century.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution was adopted by 395 votes in favour, 200 against and 71 abstentions. I was one of the members who abstained. I could not vote in favour, because the resolution, although it invokes the need for reforms within the Union, is limited to vague statements. In my opinion, reforms must be radical and be started now! Any delay or delay only aggravates the crisis in which the Union finds itself. Furthermore, although the ENF Group, of which I am a member, has tabled several amendments to the text of the resolution, none of them have been adopted. I am referring in particular to the amendment requiring that no group of States be able to take decisions on behalf of the other States, thereby violating the principle of equality between Member States. On the other hand, I could not vote against it, because I am convinced that the UK must respect the wishes of its citizens and trigger the process of leaving the EU as soon as possible.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion, as, despite regretting the outcome of the referendum in the United Kingdom, it is important to respect the will of the British citizens.  In this regard, I believe that the negotiations for the uk's withdrawal from the European Union should be carried out as soon as possible, minimising this potential economic, financial and social impact as much as possible.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the joint resolution on the decision to leave the European Union following the result of the British referendum, because the citizens have made their choice democratically and we must respect it. However, in the interests of the integrity of the Union, we call for the rapid opening of the withdrawal procedure, as stipulated in Article 50 of the EU Treaty. The British authorities must assume their responsibilities and the institutions must negotiate a new relationship with the United Kingdom, in the interests of the Union.  Brexit must be turned into an opportunity to reform the European project to refocus it on citizens' concerns. It is necessary to strengthen and improve the functioning of the Union in order to make it intelligible and relevant to the citizens. It is imperative that the European Union come out of this ordeal with its head held high, at the risk, if not, of starting the crime advocated by the Pro-Brexit British camp. We must move towards a more federal Europe giving a greater place to the European Parliament. We need a real policy of recovery, but also and above all a social policy that allows the citizen to be reconciled with the European project.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This plenary session is convened on a single issue, not so much in the affairs of the United Kingdom's internal politics, but with the future of the European Union as a whole. There is much to talk about that irresponsible British politicians have made a promise with populist promises, and now the EU as a whole will now look for a solution to this artificially created problem for two years instead of addressing current, everyday, competence-intensive and therefore populist-minded issues such as the milk market crisis, the future of agricultural policy or cohesion policy in the new financial perspective. I am convinced that the resolution we are debating today delivers the most important message: the EU is a democratic community of free states that does not restrict its members. With one Member State determined to leave, it is the duty of all remainers to ensure that the exit is as fast, smoother as possible and does not cause difficulties for all Member States and, above all, for all citizens of the European Union, especially those EU citizens who live in the UK. At the same time, our resolution does not answer the question: what will happen after the exit? How will we legitimise relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom, which is no longer a member of the EU?  I am sure that we must not do that. Let us leave the British themselves first and foremost to decide how they see their future. And we MEPs will only have to take a decision that benefits all EU citizens in response to the British proposal, together with the Council.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the result of the referendum in the United Kingdom on its exit from the European Union. The British have made the decision to leave the European Union; they have taken their responsibilities freely and it is now up to them to build their future without Europe.  Brexit is a crucial moment for European integration and we must relaunch the European project as soon as possible in order to meet the interests and expectations of citizens. In particular, it is up to the European institutions, as well as the Member States, to take responsibility and re-found the EU. But for this, we must not misdiagnose: no need for new procedures, new treaties; Europe needs politics above all else.  In order to do so, the Union must focus on the major issues to which it brings added value, as outlined in the text, and provide concrete answers to citizens regarding the enormous security, geopolitical and economic challenges facing the whole world.  We must reinvent a concrete and ambitious European project, free of any short-sighted populist temptation. It is a question of responsibility for everyone.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain from this Resolution because we understand that the will expressed at the ballot box must be respected, starting with the activation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union. We advocate that citizens can freely choose their future in democratic and transparent processes. Although we do not believe that leaving the European Union from the United Kingdom will lead to an improvement in the living conditions of its citizens. We do not agree that the outbound process will be activated immediately. We understand that the United Kingdom should legitimately assess when it will be prepared to start the process, and in no case should there be gaps with respect to the rules and treaties to which the country is subject. A process with democratic guarantees is one that guarantees the well-being of its citizens, of all people who live and work in the UK. We did not vote in favour because we thought it was essential that two amendments should come out which showed that it is essential to revive the European process in the light of inequalities and to defend the democratisation of the European institutions. They didn't get ahead and that's why our final vote was abstention.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒   I voted against the resolution because: there is no legal or political basis to insist that Article 50 TEU be activated forthwith. The UK, which remains a very important part of Europe, is in political turmoil and in no position to start negotiations on leaving the EU. Waiting till the situation stabilises there before the leave process takes off will not affect the current state of uncertainty, and is in the fundamental interests of European – including British – working people; the way forward as presented in the resolution will be incomprehensible to most European citizens and their families, and cannot appear as a response to their concerns and fears. The resolution does not ask the right questions or provide the right replies; starting a wide discussion on Treaty changes, some directed towards increased federalism when no prospects exist to bridge effectively the growing divergences between different regions of the EU, is not the right way forward. This should be consolidation and a total insistence on giving priorities to growth policies in Europe. Moreover, the approach defined by the resolution will play into the hands of forces who will see in it multiple opportunities to call new referenda.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the resolution of the European Parliament which notes the willingness of the citizens of the United Kingdom to leave the European Union and which stresses that the will of the people must be fully and fully respected, starting with the activation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union as soon as possible. We are living at a critical time for the EU, and the interests and expectations of the citizens of the Union must be brought back to the heart of the debate, and the European project must be relaunched right now. We cannot afford to create a context conducive to conflict, and we must remember that peace was the most precious gift that this common project has given us. That is why we must do everything possible to create a stronger and more citizen-oriented Union.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this joint motion because I reject a hasty resolution which aims solely to increase political pressure on the peoples of the United Kingdom following the EU exit referendum and which lacks any self-criticism towards the policies that explain the outcome of the vote.  We do not identify with the front that attributes to Europeanism the custody of democratic values, because in this Europe, that of perpetual austerity, that of the militarization of borders, that of imperialism and neoliberalism that is not able to respond to any of today's great crises, there is no future for the popular classes.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I respect the will of the British. Now it's more important to keep a cool head and not make hasty decisions. I find today's European Parliament resolution calling for Britain's swift departure as disrespectful and creating unnecessary tensions on the part of MEPs. The approach of Mr Schultz and Mr Juncker is unconstructive. I voted against. It is necessary to give the British time and focus on the negotiations that will bring about a strong partnership.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the motion for a resolution because I consider the resolution to be very proactive for a swift withdrawal of Great Britain from the EU and very insensitive to the 48% of people who voted to remain in The United Kingdom and to Scotland and Northern Ireland, which do not wish to leave. The result of the referendum must be respected, but the next steps must be taken by the representatives of Great Britain, because the referendum was with them, not in the Union. David Cameron must tell the COUNCIL of the EU the position of their government and parliament and another plan. Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union will be applicable accordingly and on the basis of a written request to leave the EU. I agree with the points in the resolution and supported those that talk about the need to reform the EU, promote our common values, ensure stability, social justice, sustainability, growth and employment, overcome persistent economic and social insecurity, protect citizens and tackle migration, which also played a significant part in the outcome of the referendum in Great Britain.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Brexit has been deeply slashed in the perception of the future of the European Union. Unfortunately, there is rhetoric among MEPs of recrimination, exclusion and finger-pointing. I believe that space should be given, above all, to the constructive dialogue that Europe desperately needs in this situation. At the moment, nothing is clear except for the great uncertainty on both the European continent and the British Isles. The resolution adopted by the European Parliament wants article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon to be activated as soon as possible, although it is clear that only the British people themselves can do so. The text should take into account the real situation and be much more looking to the future. We need clear commitments for radical changes to the EU's continued action, which must go back to and put citizens at the heart of their action. Unfortunately, I do not think that the Brexit resolution adopted is showing this, which is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. Following the referendum on Britain's remaining in the EU, a special session of the European Parliament was convened and a resolution adopted. The resolution was supported by a coalition of four political groups, including the CDU/CSU, SPD, FDP and Greens. The aim is to urge the British to leave as soon as possible. British MEPs have been asked to resign. The parliamentary colleagues from the four parties mentioned have already made it clear that they do not want to abide by the EU Treaties themselves. Article 50 of the TEU allows the UK to freely decide when to formally notify the European Council of its intention. After that, the British have two years (with a possible extension) to actually complete the exit. Until then, they will remain a member of the EU, with all their rights and obligations. I strongly condemn the approach led by Parliament President Martin Schulz on the slogan 'Who goes, let us get it done!' and I have therefore rejected the resolution. We can and must first prepare sensible trade agreements with the British. Common economic interests must not be damaged by small-scale political warfare.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted against this resolution. This resolution is completely unnecessary, because it is legally non-binding and does not impress anyone politically – certainly not the advocates of Brexit.  But it reveals the true face of the vast majority of the EP: more Europe and on as if Brexit had not happened. I cannot agree with that. In addition, the EP announces that it will "change its internal organisation to take into account the will of a majority of UK citizens to leave the European Union" – in plain language: UK MEPs will from now on be kept out of all decision-making processes. They shouldn't let that happen, because they remain full members until the divorce is pronounced. The same applies to the call for the UK to be excluded from the rotating Presidency – that is great nonsense. Above all, this resolution proves that in the European Parliament, Christian Democrats, Social Democrats, Greens and Liberals act as a grand coalition. Political accents are dissolving. Perceptible opposition work, on the other hand, is carried out only by ECR and EFDD. Let us therefore work in favour of opposition work also being carried out in the European Parliament and of recalling the behaviour of the old parties at the next elections.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the decision to leave the EU resulting from the UK referendum. Official figures clearly show that if only the votes of younger voters were taken into account, Britain would remain in the European Union, which is a very clear signal that young people who are already facing unemployment continue to want the right to live, study and work in 27 countries. Unfortunately, the populists have been much louder by pointing the finger at the European Union, saying that the main culprit is all the problems, which is not the case, of course. As soon as the results were announced, we faced the negative consequences of the referendum in the financial markets, which was most reflected by the fall in the pound to its lowest level since 1985 and the fall in spending and investment. Credit rating agencies have also downgraded Britain's credit rating in recent days, with a negative outlook. We need a unified response, which must not be incriminating, pointing the finger at others, but must be constructive and look to the future. We can't put our heads in the sand and act like nothing's happened, but we need self-reflex.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's vote on the European Parliament's resolution on the decision to leave the EU resulting from the UK referendum, I abstained because I believe that the resulting text is not adequate for the situation which, in my opinion, requires, above all, balance sheet. The result of the referendum is a clear will by the majority of UK voters to leave the EU, and I do not question that will. However, from a legal point of view, the process of withdrawal from the EU can only begin after the Member State has confirmed and notified its intention. This has not happened at the moment and I do not believe that it is absolutely necessary at this time to require notification within a matter of days. The UK Government is responsible for announcing the will to leave the EU, and we should respect that responsibility. Therefore, from this legal point of view or in the interests of future friendly cooperation between the EU and the United Kingdom, I believe that it is now not appropriate to publish hastily prepared political resolutions announcing, inter alia, changes in the internal organisation of the European Parliament (i.e. personnel changes) a few days after the referendum, at a time when the UK is still an EU Member State.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European project has clearly failed. On 23 June British citizens decided that their future is outside the EU and under no circumstances should the EU show vengeful tendencies against Britain.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fidesz and KDNP MPs regret the decision of the CITIZENS of the United Kingdom. We supported this Decision of the European Parliament, together with the members of the European People's Party, because we believe that the opinion of the majority of Britons must be respected and that the remaining members of the European Union must ensure stability and the promotion of their interests. The text adopted in this resolution is the result of a compromise between the parliamentary factions and we therefore do not agree with all the elements of it. We miss and regret the lack of self-critical elements of the text concerning the Union, the reasons that led to the victory of those who want to leave, such as the Union's flawed immigration policy, frequent violations of subsidiarity by the EU institutions, a lack of functioning European solutions, delays in EU decision-making, frequent disregard for the aspects of national parliaments. We do not think the urgent tone is right, because the process must take place in compliance with the EU Treaties and the British constitutional order. We also considered it unnecessary for the European Parliament to call on the Council to represent the Union in the procedure, since, under Article 50 TSI, the appointment of a negotiator, which may also be the Commission, falls within the competence of the Council.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a resolution outlining the situation created by the result of the referendum on Britain's exit from the EU and the challenges and actions of the EU. I welcome the fact that the European Parliament takes a strong and almost unified position in this regard in order to clarify as soon as possible the uncertain legal and political situation following the British decision, in particular the initiation and conduct of proceedings without time under Article 50 of the Treaty (TEU). I am convinced that this is in the interests of both the British people and the Union, especially those EU Member States, including my own country, which are facing similar domestic political challenges with nationalist ions. As a forward-looking element of the decision, I strongly support the EP's belief in continuing and strengthening European integration, making better use of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon, or even treaty change. As a Socialist politician, I think it is particularly important that job creation and social justice are a priority in the formulation of this. I believe that, with the decision adopted in this extraordinary plenary session, the European Parliament has once again taken the political initiative to deal with the situation after the British referendum, and I will actively support our continued primary role in this.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution. The British finally said no to Europe. It is of course a failure, but it can become an opportunity. A failure, because the European project as it is, no longer convinces the crowds, a failure also for David Cameron who, in order to get re-elected, opened a Pandora's box that he never managed to close. But it is also an opportunity: to start a new job on a good basis by profoundly reforming the rules of operation and the European institutions, with the Member States really motivated by the project, and avoiding proposing a Europe à la carte: a Europe that works and responds more effectively to the expectations of the citizens. This will require a profound questioning!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The result of the British referendum is a massive shock for the EU which will lose one of its important Members. It is a unique case in EU History and we must not underestimate the impact of such a decision for the future of the Union. EU leaders and institutions need to provide a clear answer and agenda to this extraordinary situation. I nevertheless decided to abstain on this resolution, not because of the content which I share to a large extent, but because of the excessive pressure put on the British Government. If I wish the European Parliament to be fully involved in all stages of the procedures regarding both the agreement for the United Kingdom’s exit and any future relationship between it and the future Union of 27 Member States, and the negotiation to start as soon as possible, I do not believe that calling for the immediate triggering of Article 50 of the Treaty is the best way to proceed.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. In a referendum, the citizens of the United Kingdom decided that their country should leave the European Union. I agree with Parliament's position set out in this resolution that their will must be respected. However, it is the Member State that must decide when to trigger Article 50. contract and I don't see any need to rush the whole process and push our partners into an uncomfortable position given the fact that incumbent Prime Minister Cameron resigned from the post after the referendum. If we want a clean, swift and transparent process for the UK's exit from the EU, this process must be led by political officials whose legitimacy is in no way questioned. I believe that by rushing the whole process, Parliament wants to avoid discussing the reasons why UK citizens want to leave the EU, and this is very dangerous and will lead to more instability.  Also, I cannot agree with calls for further integration. The response to the EU's deep political, identity and institutional crisis cannot be a simple mantra about "more Europe", especially when it is quite clear that european union citizens do not want it. For these reasons, I voted against this resolution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's joint resolution on the outcome of the UK referendum. While I deeply regret the result, I believe that the people's decision must be respected and, therefore, start the process of Britain's withdrawal from the European Union as soon as possible.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution for the following reasons: the BREXIT referendum has been a form of direct democracy and the European Parliament shall respect the will of the British people. Furthermore, we cannot keep in the Union nations against their free will. The EU faces numerous challenges. We all have to improve the economy, to protect European values and to meet security challenges with an open visor. Furthermore, I believe that the only solution to the current crisis is implementation of the principle of ‘ever closer union’ with common fiscal and tax policies, common migration and refugee policies, and last but not least, a common EU army and efficient security policies.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain from this Resolution because we understand that the will expressed at the ballot box must be respected, starting with the activation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union. We advocate that citizens can freely choose their future in democratic and transparent processes. Although we do not believe that leaving the European Union from the United Kingdom will lead to an improvement in the living conditions of its citizens. We do not agree that the outbound process will be activated immediately. We understand that the United Kingdom should legitimately assess when it will be prepared to start the process, and in no case should there be gaps with respect to the rules and treaties to which the country is subject. A process with democratic guarantees is one that guarantees the well-being of its citizens, of all people who live and work in the UK. We did not vote in favour because we thought it was essential that two amendments should come out which showed that it is essential to revive the European process in the light of inequalities and to defend the democratisation of the European institutions. They didn't get ahead and that's why our final vote was abstention.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution mainly because I do not agree with the push to trigger Article 50 quickly, which is entirely the responsibility of the UK Government. Furthermore, I reject calls for stronger integration in response to the current situation. The European Union must reform to bring it closer to its citizens and to ensure greater respect for the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ First of all I would like to say that we have to respect the outcome of the British vote and the will of the people. We cannot ignore it, we have to respect it. Now the EU and the UK should follow a pragmatic approach and try to get the best deals in the interest of all parties. Finally, regarding Scotland, I fully support the Pro-European work and message of the SNP and the very important work their leader Nicola Sturgeon will have to undertake in coming months. My dear colleague Alyn Smith said it very well today: ‘Scotland didn’t let the EU down, now don’t let Scotland down!’ I fully share this view and sentiment.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I opted for abstention in this vote on such an important and sensitive issue, as I would have liked the European Parliament's position to be more nuanced.  I believe, first of all, that the European Parliament forum should pay more attention to respect for the rights of European citizens on the territory of the United Kingdom, in particular in the context of increased xenophobic-racist abuses and attacks. In this regard, I call on the British authorities to act firmly to defend Romanian citizens working in the United Kingdom, and I am referring in particular to the case of the Barbu family, whose children, exclusively Romanian citizens, have been wrongfully entrusted with the adoption of a British couple.  With regard to the need for reform of the EU, I regret the lack of anticipation of the competent Community institutions and the slow pace of developing appropriate responses to the crises that are attacking the European project. Unfortunately, the resolution lists key common values, without providing solutions and deadlines for overcoming decision-making gridlock and lack of vision that exacerbates the current IMPASSE of the EU. I am also concerned about the attempt to formalise a multi-speed Europe, without transparency as to the possible intentions of some of the Member States and without an analysis of the implications for the EU as a whole.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this common motion because I reject a hasty resolution which aims solely to increase political pressure on the peoples of the United Kingdom following the EU exit referendum and which lacks any self-criticism towards the policies that explain the outcome of the vote.  We do not identify with the front that attributes to Europeanism the custody of democratic values, for in this Europe, that of perpetual austerity, that of the militarization of borders, that of imperialism and neoliberalism there is no future for the popular classes.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution tabled together by the liberal, socialist, Christian Democratic and Green groups. We ask that the negotiations on the UK's exit be led by the European Commission and not by the Council. The European Parliament is calling for the UK to submit the Article 50 application for withdrawal from the Union as soon as possible, in order to show that it responds to the demands of the British people. The European Union also needs to be adapted: more compact, focused and with less heavy administration, more Europe to better meet the demands of the people.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 During the vote on the motion for a resolution on the UK's withdrawal from the EU, I supported the line that the EU Parliament would stop to consider the effects of the referendum in favour of the UK's withdrawal from the EU on a wider scale. I could not support a resolution in which the spirit is to continue to develop the Union towards deeper integration than nothing would have happened. I am in favour of developing the Union as a union of states in which the decision-making power lies with the people and the nation states. I believe that the Union must be developed in this direction, rather than the current line of closer integration.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Members of the European Parliament deplore and condemn the way the Directory of Powers of the European Union acts in the face of a legitimate and sovereign decision of the people of the United Kingdom. The way in which this resolution uses and manipulates the invocation of Article 50 OF the EU to initiate the process of the UNITED KINGDOM leaving the EU, wanting it to be fully conditioned by the will of the directory of powers and conducted in the institutions of the European Union dominated by it, demonstrates the objective of basing this process on blackmail and pressure on the free decision of the British people. In the face of such an event of such great political importance, the majority of the EP reaffirms the very same direction of the European Union, arguing that the way is to strengthen political, economic, monetary and militaristic integration.  CFP Members reaffirm that another Europe is necessary and possible. A Europe that rejects exploitation and oppression and is based on cooperation, peace, solidarity, mutual respect and the defence of the sovereignty of peoples.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The text is clearly a desire to cover up elements of self-criticism that Brexit was actually caused by a flawed EU policy. Instead, the text seems as if the British have done something wrong. Our amendments are aimed in particular at Juncker's resignation and at taking note and recognising the result. The result of the British referendum must be respected by the EU.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. This resolution clearly shows that in Brussels the vote of the citizens of the United Kingdom, whose majority in favour of leaving the EU is also transferable to the populations of many other EU states, has not been understood. Forcibly, the rest of the union is now to be transformed into a kind of federal state in order to make further secessions more difficult in the future. This motion for a resolution must therefore be rejected.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party voted against the joint resolution of the People's Party, the Social Democrats, the Liberals and the Greens on "the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU". The resolution seeks, in the context of fierce opposition and competition, to set the terms of the EU monopolies for the conclusion of the agreement to leave the EU. It also attempts, as the propaganda of the SYRIZA-ANEL government does, to present the EU, this union of monopolies, as a supposed defender of popular interests, sowing illusions that the EU can "reform, become better, more democratic" etc. The EU cannot become pro-grassroots. It serves the capital and therefore only worse for the people can be done. The working class and the other poor working classes have the only way out with their struggle to overthrow the power of capitalists and with the keys to the economy in their hands to impose in their interest the release from the EU, NATO and any other alliance of capital.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the motion for a joint resolution on the outcome of the referendum in the United Kingdom. Although I regret that the majority of the people of Great Britain have decided to leave the European Union, I respect their decision and I think that, once this decision has been made, we should focus pragmatically on the process of leaving. However, unlike the joint motion for a resolution, I do not believe that we should push Great Britain immediately and immediately until the whole process is started, or push British MEPs to give up their mandate. What we need at the moment is not an insulting response and an attempt to show the UK that it will be much worse off without the EU, but we need to move away from complacency and focus on ourselves and try to manage the situation with a cool head for the best possible future for our continent. Above all, we need to strive for the best possible relations between the reformed European Union and Great Britain, because making the situation and the withdrawal negotiations more difficult can, in the end, only add arguments to the various extreme political parties and views in the other Member States.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because I consider it deeply unfair to the people of the United Kingdom. We in the 5 Star Movement are only interested in seeing the will of the people respected as emerged from the referendum. It is not for the European Parliament to force the procedures laid down in Article 50 to be speeded up, which is not even one of Parliament's prerogatives.  The situation is complex and unprecedented. It seems absurd that the resolution, given the outcome of the referendum, does not include serious self-criticism and does not analyse the faults of Europe itself. Together with my colleagues in the 5 Star Movement, we have proposed in an amendment that the Council should give the Commission a well-defined political mandate and we have also called for a situation of discrimination against British MEPs, due to a likely change in parliamentary organisation, to be avoided. In the light of the result of the referendum, for us in the 5-Star Movement, the resignation of Commission President Juncker is essential and we have strongly demanded them.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the decision to leave the EU, which was the result of a referendum in the UK. I agree that a reflection on the future of the Union is needed, and I believe that we must protect the integrity of the Union and its citizens by promoting common values, ensuring stability and social security, providing jobs and effectively addressing the challenges of migration. Therefore, the notification provided for in Article 50 TEU should be issued as soon as possible in order to avoid uncertainty which would be detrimental to all.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned. (The sitting was closed at 12.10 p.m.)
